reviewText:
I don’t like real time strategy or tower defense games, you can’t out click a computer and they usually cheat.  So it’s seem odd that I would even buy this game, let alone log 196 hours (wait, how many? I’m not even done with the Play+.)  What made the game appeal to me was the RPG element.  I like RPGs, it’s reassuring to know you can grind and level up to make up for your lack of skill and intelligence.
The game offers 25 stages plus bonus levels that are all replayable (didn’t realize that’s not a real word) at not just different difficulties but also with a different mix of enemies.  There are only six characters (towers) but each has 10 or so skills which adds to the variety.  There are 19 enemies including repallets (figured that wasn’t a real word) and five bosses.
The best part is the characters.  The dialogue and interaction is engrossing often hilarious.  The replay mode unlocks Azra’s diary with extra (also hilarious) insight to her background and the other characters (SPOILER ALERT!! Slak knows how to read and write.)
In conclusion (that never gets old,) Defender’s Quest: title too long is a great mix of tower defense and RPG.  Most importantly, it’s fun.  If you had to pay all 15 bucks for this game, it’s worth it.  If it should happen to be on sale around Thanksgiving or Christmas (or whatever other holiday you celebrate on your fast track to hell) you’d be a fool not to buy it (unless you’ve got something better to do with 196 hours, like work.)

reviewText:
You start it up and notice the game doesn't rescale to your desktop native res and you feel like just passing it by but with all those great user reviews I stuck for a while... and the game itself is rock solid. Fun RPG/Tower mechanics with a lot of variation and the reward for succesful experimentation is goodies that enable to tackle even harder challenges.

The story/characters in the game are fine and entretaining as well but it's the gameplay that will keep you enthused and enthralled and maybe even captivated till you fully master it. Even if you just beat it all on normal mode it's well worth its asking price.

Pick it up and enjoy, easy to recommend even for non genre fans.

reviewText:
This is a surprisingly good little tower defense game with RPG mechanics. As a commander, you can recruit troops, equip them with weapons and armor and control their few skills when leveling up. It is pretty basic, yet very deep. The levels are single screen and grid based. You place your characters down and they automatically attack as enemies approach them. There are 6 classes, a basic melee, long range, healer, ice mage, slow defensive breaker and all powerful dragon with short and long range attacks. It costs PSI to place your characters, and more PSI to retract them (to move them).

How do you get PSI? Well you start with it, but then as you kill enemies, you gain more PSI and you have a maximum of course. You are defending a summoner against the waves of enemies and the summoner (your player character) can take a beating and has plenty of HP, so the game is forgiving, but rewarding if you make it through the level without being damaged.

You can 'boost' your characters at the cost of PSI. There are many levels of boos that enable skills that you've unlocked through leveling up your characters. When you level up your characters, you select their perk. Which has a simple perk tree of skills and passive abilities. It is a nice little system, but I find myself making the same perk choices instead of diversifying.

Oh and death is not perminant for your characters. If someone dies, just use PSI to bring them back. If your player character dies, you lose the level and need to restart. These levels are quick, especially at 4x speed, so nothing is really lost.

While the game boasts a rich story.... I found myself hitting the skip button. I just don't play games for the story. You read the story as you unlock new levels and progress through a Mario World style map with all of the levels plotted as map points.

The game is very easy to pick up and play, but not just that, it encourages replaying the levels with 3 different difficulties (and a 'casual' difficulty as a 4th). If there's an insurmountable level.... replay old levels *cough* grind. But replaying old levels never seems like a chore, its more of a joy. Even if you keep replaying the same level on the same difficulty, every playthrough is different, since your characters level up and you can change your tactics.

The game is a lot of fun, and while its deep, its never overwhelmingly deep. There's not an overwhelming micro management either, even if you can micro manage everything.

I highly recommend it. Its a fun little game, relaxing and never gets all that intense. I found myself playing it on 4x speed and that seems like it should be the average speed. Is it worth the $15? Its a game you can sink hours and hours into, so you'll get a lot of relaxing playtime for your dollar.

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Defender Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a 2D game with a unique blend of TD and RPG from Level Up Labs. It features characters / companions who act as 'towers' and need to be strategically placed around the map to defend your main character Azra. Unlike a tower defense game, however, you can level up and equip items for your companions to help them improve in combat.

You take the role of Azra, a royal librarian of the Kingdom of Ash which is currently being ravaged by a plague. Azra gets infected and thrown into 'The Pit', a place where all dead or dying are placed to keep the kingdom safe because those who die from the Plague become 'Revenants', undead monsters that are immune to physical harm. Azra soon discovers that she has the power to enter both the living world and the 'Half-Way' world, a place between the living realm & the realm of the dead. In this realm, she can summon her companions to fight the Revenants in their spirit form and eventually kill them.

PROS:+ Refreshing new mix of genres
+ 8-bit sprite art style that works well with the game
+ Character / Companion progression is deep and extensive
+ Well designed Maps and Mazes
+ Very challenging difficulty levels
+ 6 base classes (towers) which can progress into different builds depending on your play-style
+ Dialogues between characters are humorous
+ Steam Workshop support

CONS:- Cutscene art work could use a lot of improvement (especially the character designs)
- Story is a bit weak
- Balance issues (some classes are outright better than others)
- Some necessary but boring grinding sessions to progress
- No real 'HD' or Widescreen Support
- No Steam Cloud Support

CONCLUSION:It is a GOOD GAME and one of the better tower defense games out there. I can easily recommend this game if you're looking for a challenging and unique game since it mixes RPG elements to the tried-and-tested Tower Defense genre. The 8-bit sprites, animations and effects are nice and work well with the game's art style although the Cutscene artwork could really use improvements. The levels are very well planned and are fun to play. Finally, the in-game dialogue between your companions is funny and quite entertaining.

I can easily RECOMMEND this game even at full price since it’s only $14.99 or your regional equivalent. With simple graphics, this game is not system requirement heavy and can easily run even on netbook computers making this a perfect game when you're on vacation, working, passing the time, or in any other situation where you are not with your main gaming system.

reviewText:
To start off, I just wanted to state that I am NOT a fan of tower defense type games. I find them repetitive, grindy, bland, and not innovative.

BUT, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a true gem in the tower defense genre. It combines the elements of a tower defense game along with rpg elements, which gives the game a surprisingly fun twist. Instead of just placing troops that do not have meaning around, I was able to level up my characters and as I progressed I learned their stories.

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is not only a tower defense game, it has a story, unlike many games of the same genre. The story was nothing special, but there was a story nonetheless.

If you're an achievement hunter (♥♥♥♥♥) like I am, then you'll be disappointed because a few of the achievements are a bit grindy. On the other hand, the developers were nice enough to allow you to go into the Options and increase exp and gold gain by 300%. I cannot stress enough how this option is amazing and that I think more devs should implement it, because of how grindy some achievements are. This also makes the game a little bit more on the easier side. I hardly ever lost a round. I can count on both hands how many times I've lost.

The game is very simple, I was able to beat the base game without generic recruits. I did recruit the generic characters in order to obtain all the gold stars/side quests. The UI is also very simple. Skill trees are simple. Everything about this game is very simple, easy to learn, and relaxing.

If you're looking for a casual game, then I'd definitely recommend this game. A lot of times, I find myself on this game when I am watching tv or a movie.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten. It's a true gem of it's genre and should not be dismissed so easily, just because it's a casual tower defense game.

reviewText:
At first glance, Defender's Quest appears to be a silly little indie game with big dreams. The characters are bright and cartoony, and their dialogue is marked with sass. Their battle sprites display whimsical touches, like the ranger who spins her bow before firing. One of the promotional spellbooks Azra can equip, the Book of Face, introduces the Internet's beloved Trollface to the otherwise sword-and-sorcery setting. Focusing on the one-liners would be simple, as they are good. However, the core plot has heft: it would make a good Dungeons and Dragons campaign or fantasy adventure novel. Royal librarian Azra must survive in a quarantine pit the size of a small nation, while she's pursued by mysterious figures. It features conspiracy, betrayal, and explosions. Careful gamers shouldn't be surprised a USDA-certified English major wrote the script. The wacky comedy and childish in-fighting among Azra's companions allows the team to quickly bond. These light-hearted intra-party friendships and feuds add personal stakes to the more pervasive dangers of the pit. The story is delivered in slideshow style before every town and battle, tying the narrative neatly to combat.

Combat is handled like a tower defense game. Enemies travel in waves from spawn points. As they walk into the attack range of stationary heroes, they suffer the effects of the heroes' attacks. The heroes are unable to move from where they're summoned, as they're doing combat on a spiritual plane where bodies just get in the way. The cornerstone of battle strategy comes from placing the six types of heroes in the appropriate location. After recruiting story characters (such as Slak, the madcap, murderous berserker), faceless extras of the same type become hirable. If that's all there was to combat, it would be a delightful diversion. However, each character gains experience points, which can be spent to learn new combat skills or boost existing ones. Once learned, most of these skills can't be used immediately. Characters must be boosted in battle, which draws from the same Psi pool Astra uses to summon allies and cast spells of her own. It can be a challenging balancing act to position the proper allies, keep them boosted, reposition troops to respond to new threats, and maintain wide scale battlefield control with Azra's spells. Thankfully, slowing the game's speed (and pausing it altogether) are simple options. The keyboard commands are simple to learn and encourage faster play, but nothing's wrong with the mouse either.

With all the moving parts that go into battle, the multiple levels of accessibility are a nice touch. Each character has nine different attack modes including attack the strongest enemy" and "attack the enemy with least immunity to status effects." Understanding the interplay between these attack modes isn't necessary for most of the core game
date: but integral to completing the optional levels. Furthermore
recommended: failure isn't necessarily punished. The default settings infer experience and money penalties for losing battles
hoursPlayed: but these can be changed based on individual preference. Redistributing skill points to explore different character builds costs money
voteText: but not a fortune. The steepest cost is the time it takes to click through all the advancements. The largest concession to the casual-vs.-hardcore debate is the option to increase experience points. Players who care more for the story and the thrill of rapid advancement can run with it. Players who want their hardcore bragging rights can lift their noses at the low-hanging fruit. True challenge-jockeys can set their sights on the more exclusive achievements
helpfulPercent: many of which are challenging even with gushing wells of experience points.\n\nDefender's Quest is a short game

reviewText:
Now that we have real reviews I wanted to give this game a better response.
As a long time tower defense player, I have to say this game is in the top 3 of all time. I'll try to explain why I love it so much, and why I'm so excited for the sequel that was recently announced.

Mechanics

This game provides somewhat traditional mechanics if you're familiar with TD games. Players can build units on the perimeter of the path only, so there is no blocking/routing mechanics to worry about. Unit's have different attack types that are better and worse for some situations
What is unique about this game is that units level up in a persistent manner between levels, allowing your units to grow over time, This included an entire skill tree for each class of units that can be customized to your play style. Additionally, units have a weapon and armor equipment slot and the game does a good job of making this meaningful by introducing rare equipment a bit later in the game.
Levels are replayable so you can grind your team a bit if you feel a little weak or would like to beef up a bit before a boss level. To compliment this aspect of the game, each level can be played on different difficulty levels, which provide bigger rewards at the cost of a higher difficulty. This aspect of the game kept me going back and trying to beat my records and old levels in order to get some of the better rare gear.
Lastly, the game features a fast forward mode which is a welcome sight for those who play a lot of tower defense games. It really helps grinding out those later levels.

Story

It's rare for a TD game to have an in-depth story, but Defender's Quest does a great job with this. It's not ground breaking, but it certainly sets a nice tone and even introduces a bit of moral dilemma that plays into the unit mechanics later in the game. I won't spoil it, but I will say that the level of narrative impressed me, and kept me engaged until the end.

Graphics/Sounds

All standard stuff here. You can look at the screenshots and get an idea of what you're into. In general I'd say that the graphics do a good job of matching the needs of the gameplay, and the animations are smooth and crisp even during hectic late game levels. The graphics change into a pleasant style during story segments and do a good job of relaying the emotion and facial expressions of the characters.

Summary

All in all, this game really scratched a Tower Defense/RPG itch that I'd been craving for a long time. If you can pick the game up on sale and like TD games I'd recommend buying it without hesitation.

reviewText:
I've played a lot of tower defense. I used to play Warcraft III custom maps where the tower defense genre was cut from. Defender's Quest does a nice job of putting a well developed story with well developed characters into tower defense gameplay without it feeling pasted on.

It keeps it simple. There are only a few basic towers to choose from, but each tower acts like a character in your party and you can equip most of them with weapons and armor (no weapons or armor for a dragon and no armor for the barbarian/main melee guy). The maps are laid out well enough that consideration to where to place your troops does make a big difference.

There is also a nice take on the gameplay by offering 4 difficulty levels. You get rewards for completing the level, but you get bonus rewards for not taking a single point of damage. If you do that, you can get a lot of extra scrap (money) and unique items.

What I'm doing on my second playthrough is going as far as I possibly can while only buying recruits and never any items on the easiest mode. When I hit my first failure, I go back to the very start and try to complete each level on the hardest mode possible. After I fail once, I will go down to an easier mode and so on until I am right back at the easiest mode and therefore, the furthest out I've ever been.

The main game is not that long and there isn't a ton of replayability to this game once you complete it. That is why it is only worth a few bucks...but it's worth a few bucks. I hear they are making a Defender's Quest II and I hope that is at least as good. Even when it is, this is still a pretty fun tower defense and something that feels more refreshing than you might think when you come back to it after a long time.

If you're a person who likes turned based rpgs, there is alot of the elements of being able to take your time and strategize, while all the same, you can just charge through really quick once you know your strengths, and how to use them most effectively.

And lastly, If you love a good laugh that was written and delivered amazingly, you should totally name all the main characters after your friends and loved ones. It makes for a good laugh, and you think of your friends, slightly helping the social aspect of the brain, while completely being absorbed into this great single player game, that will make you think your not alone in playing it for so many hours...and if you're not really alone inside your head, well that makes the adventure even more interesting!  Such a great game. I recommend it a few times over.

Well, reviewing a title that is available for 2 years now seems useless, yet i'll do it anyway :-)

try to outfit them with better weapons and armor. I surely had my fun. Would be even worth fullprice!"

reviewText:
A mix of tower defense, strategy, and RPG genres combine to make what is Defender’s Quest. The game revolves around a linear campaign to save the world from the forces of, um, evil.

My only strike against this game is that the RPG element feels rather tacky; for awhile you actually care about the skill points you assign to your party but once you have a solid dozen or more of characters you pretty much don't care anymore and just assign skill points in a sometimes arbitrary manner.

That said, Defender's Quest is a good game that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys thought provoking tower defense games.

reviewText:
Like many others have said, let me start this by saying I don't like tower defense games. At all. Those have never held my interest for too long. Despite this, I bought this game after Rock Paper Shotgun showcased it many, many years ago.

If I had to choose my favorite indie game, it would be Defender's Quest for sure. Nothing else comes even close. The developers have done a great job at supporting the game throughout the years, first by releasing a Gold version (that is the current Steam version) as well as planning to release the HD version of the game that comes for free for all owners of the game on Steam. Defender's Quest 2 is also in the works as of writing of this review.

If you like tower defenses, get this game. If you like witty dialogue, get this game. This game shows what an indie game can be when it's done right. I can't really find any real flaws out of it.

reviewText: Defender's QUest is a tower defense game that has a heart. The video trailer is pithy, suggesting that the game and its creators don't take themselves seriously, but don't be fooled. The story is simple but effective, not avoiding the cliches but embracing them and making them its own, but not with the wink and nod of the lampooner, but of a storyteller with an earnest wish to convey to you the world they've imagined. I found myself playing this game long after the challenge had worn away, drawn not so much by the game that had grown to be child's play after intense leveling, but rather by that very soul the creators instilled in it. I found myself surprised by this, and was sad to find it 100% completed and with nothing more to offer. I will pick you up again in time, my friend, for the happiness you offered was not forgotten.

reviewText:
This is my favourite game in years.
It's a tower defense game where each of what would normally be a tower is actually a character that levels up, like in an RPG, complete with a customizable skill tree, equipment, etc. These levels are earned from level to level, so you're constantly improving your party.

This superficially simple gameplay concept is backed up on all sides by a great story, deep strategy elements and amazing replayability.

Story
Azra (or the name you choose) is the royal librarian that ends up in The Pit, a wretched place full of zombie-like creatures called Revenant. Using mysterious special powers (that excellently explain the tower defense gameplay) and the help of a band of ragtag adventures you'll pick up it is your job to guide her out of the pit. There is more at stake, and the plot has plenty of developments to keep you interested, but what surprised me the most were the story's pacing and its humour.
No story segment lasts more than a minute or two, excluding the ending but not the opening, yet it tells a cohesive and engaging story. You'll never feel like the levels are just there to pad out the story or vice versa.

Strategy & Replayability
Within levels you get to place your defenders along the paths your enemies will take to reach Azra. Doing so spends mana, so unless Azra has a lot of Mana (maximum mana increases by increasing her level) you'll need to consider which allies to summon. You can 'boost' these allies to unlock more attacks and increase their core stats, up to 5 times, this is equivalent to the traditional tower defense game's tower upgrade. Combine that with being able to place allies whenever you want, advanced targetting settings and certain allies working very well together while others negate some aspects of other powers (frozen vs. burning) and you have a deeply rewarding tactical system.
Is this required to enjoy or finish the game? No.

The ability to play and replay any level you've cleared at any of 4 difficulties means that you set your own pace and your own challenge. On the lowest difficulty you can basically breeze through the game and just enjoy the story, never having to put a lot of thought into tactics or grinding, and the hardest difficulty will have you either rethinking your tactics or grinding a few more levels.
Clearing the game once, with any of its 5 endings (only 2 distinct ones really, one just has 4 different versions) will unlock new game+ mode parallel to the regular game mode. This features new powers for all enemies, several sidequests telling the story of one of the characters relevant to the plot, the ability to understand the 'ancient language' spoken in some of the dialogue and a 'journal' that offers lovely (and often hilarious) glances into the protagonist's mind as her journey progresses.
It will challenge you and reward you, and this is completely free extra content that was released months after the game was originally launched that is automatically included. I've put dozens of hours into this game and still revisit it regularly to see if I can't beat a few of the levels I still have problems with on a higher difficulty or to work on my Hero Mode run.

Summary:
+great plot
+great tower defense gameplay
+great RPG-style customization
+replay levels
+multiple difficulties
+multiple endings
+best way to do new game+
-graphics are serviceable, but nothing to write home about
-no voice acting (which to me is better than bad voice acting...)
-Defender's Quest 2 isn't out yet, give it to meeeeee!
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Defender's Quest is a huge little gem of a game. I believe it offers the most hours of fun per megabyte of any Steam game I've played yet. I really enjoyed playing through it twice and sweating enough to unlock all the achievements.

The game scales in difficulty exponentially. This means that the easiest battles are actually the earliest, and that the game gets harder as it progresses. This is a welcome change from most games, but it's taken to an unnecessary extreme at the end. Finishing the final 10% of a full 201 star playthrough will be where you spend the majority of your time. Thanks to the level cap - which you will get to - you'll hit a wall in your ability to improve. That makes it feel repetitive and slow, because you're just repeating the same few battles over and over again, trying to make little tweaks to survive. Most of the game isn't like that, but it's a frustrating way to finish.

The game's story and characters are quite memorable and well-written. The dialogue is funny. I wasn't expecting that at all, especially from a tower defense game. It's actually one of the main reasons I'm looking forward to the sequel: I want to know what happens in this world to these people.

The graphics are a huge let down though. With no way to scale the sprites are locked in a tiny window. I found myself squinting just to tell what was going on. And I heavily considered lowering my resolution just to make things bigger. Thankfully an HD re-release is in the works, but the level of fidelity as is leaves the game looking like a B-level mobile game.

Defender's Quest is not without flaws, but if you enjoy challenging tower defense gameplay where the story compels you to move forward then it's well worth a purchase.

reviewText:
This game. This is most likely the biggest surprise in my entire library.

I originally bought this game about two years ago. The Steam Trading Card system  had just launched into beta (remember when everyone thought it was going to be huge and a card could be worth $5?) and I had gotten in. Curious to test the system out, I found I at the time did not own any games on the short list of applicable games. I immediately did two things. First, I purchased Half-Life 2 since I had played that game on another account and knew it was good. Second was I started scanning the list for cheap games. This was on a daily deal sale the following day.

I checked it out and saw that is seemed like a pretty generic, if solid, tower defense game. Felt like one of those particularly good flash games on something like Kongregate or Armor Games. Still, for 5 bucks, I figured it was worth a shot.

And I wasn't entirely wrong in my expectations. This does very much feel like a buffed up flash game in a lot of ways. And then I asked myself if that was a bad thing. The gameplay is simple and understandable yet plenty difficult. Creativity is encouraged and different strategies will be required. The graphics weren't amazing, certainly not HD (though a HD update is on its' way at time of writing) but I feel like the art has character to it. This of course is helped by the fact that there actuually is a solid storyline in the game, more than many games I've played. The characters don't have a lot of screentime for development, yet I still feel like they are real.

All in all, this game I found to be a very good surprise. Don't expect a AAA level game, but do expect a game whose simple charm and solid gameplay will leave you satisfied. This game doesn't amaze, but it does the one thing that all games have to do. It's simply entertaining. The devs (who btw are super communicative and dedicated to their games) really did a great job with this one, and I look forward to their future work.

9/10 - Highly Reccomended

reviewText: As tower defense games go, this is a really good one!  I really like that on each level you can change the difficulty from calm to challenging to frustrating - so I can set it for whatever mood I feel like playing in. reviewText: My first sleeper surprise this year.  Hardly anyone sings praises of Defender's Quest, with its basic visuals, repetitive music, and seemingly cloned gameplay.  I'm sure other games have tried combining RPG and Tower Defense (just as Puzzle Quest did with RPG and match 3 puzzles), but I was sucked into this game quicker than I imagined.  The story is dumb but you come to like the silly dialogue and characters, and the stages tend to change just enough (at least on higher difficulties) so you have to keep on your toes.  Some levels will remove your archers for example, while others may force you to prioritize on certain enemies rather than the collective.  This is a great game for people who enjoy Tower Defense with the loot collecting and skill customization of RPGs.

reviewText:
[Spoiler-Free Review]

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is the definition of a hidden gem. The game is amazing, but criminally overlooked.

The game plays something akin to a Fire Emblem: Tower Defense where stat and character growth elements are mixed with strategy and storyline. Acquiring new gear for your party (via extra challenges) as you progress through the story arc elicits the same feeling of excitement, joy and wonder I had when I was a child exploring Final Fantasy for the first time in glorious 16-bit. The music is genius in it's simplicity, the graphics are a throwback to the olden days, and the story is interesting from the get-go.

If there's fault I can find within the game it's that the difficulty balance in some of the stages leans too heavily on the easy side (when set to normal difficulty in-game). I find myself pining for an extreme or endless mode, or better yet, a colosseum with extremely rare equipment and rewards.

Buy this game; It's going to amaze you.

I didn't come into this game with any expectations. I hadn't even heard of it before I saw the trailer on the bundle, but this game actually ended up being fantastic. Overall, I'm so glad I played this. Thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
I'll admit I am biased; I absolutely love this game.
The writing is smart and to the point. It gives these characters who could've fit a dull archetype much more personality and energy. There is both levity and gravity. Our leading ladies are represented very well and are good examples of female characters.
Gameplay is very user friendly, but in a good way. It doesn't matter if you are new to Tower Defense games or a pro, you can customize the game to fit your wants. Want a challenge but don't want to grind? Crank up the exp and only use the main characters. Is it kicking your butt? Decreased the penalty for losing. It's very intuitive.
Music although noted to be repetitive suits the mood very well. The mood of peril and danger is conveyed very well and the music is catchy enough to be memorable.

Here's a TL;DR
The Good
+Great writing
+Challenging but not required
+Anti-grind measures
+Replayability with New Game Plus

The Bad
-Flat character designs
-Certain maps with a lot of action can slow down computers
-Will likely have to resort to using the lightning spell which makes it a click-fest

Among the many, many other TD games, this game rises far above crowd.

reviewText:
A fun spin on the tower defence genre. Adding character growth and party management similar to something like Final Fantasy Tactics stop it from becoming stale like a lot of other tower defence games. The stat trees don't seem especially deep, but they're interesting enough in the early game and everything seems well balanced.

The story is simple but well told, the art style is also very simple (the 6th party member/character type in particular looks a little goofy) but the character of the game shines through it, and your party members are all expressive, interesting and actually quite charming. Lots of good, strong female characters here as well which is refreshing.

Each level has an advanced and extreme version, which will require you to come back later when you're stronger. They're unnecessary to progress, but they will give you extra goodies if you go back and do them.

Currently on sale for $1.50, which is a steal, I'd consider it well worth it at the regular $15 for fans of good tower defence or tactics based RPGs.

reviewText: Being a sucker for tower defense games, I snagged this game up fairly quickly when I noticed it was on sale. This game is simply awesome, it has everything a TD enthusiast could ever hope for. The game is quite challenging, which I consider a plus when playing TD games. Even when your characters are max level and you've obtained all the best gear it's still quite hard in the later stages of NG+.  Unit placement is extremely important as well as choosing the right skills/passives for your characters based on the level you're playing. The characters are very likable and a bit comedic at times. I usually mute games and play my own music but I rarely did that with this game, the soundtrack is quite enjoyable. reviewText:
TL;DR: If you ever even remotely enjoyed a tower defense type of game, you seriously need to play this one. If you haven't but like rpgs, this is your best bet to find out what a great TD can be like, with the RPG elements to help carry you along. Really, if the (very generous) demo to this game doesn't get you hooked, then tower defense may simply not be your genre, and at least now you know. ;)

*** ***

Defender's Quest is one of those games that without too much fanfare and fancy graphics simply get gameplay right. The rpg elements are well embedded, the story is not just an excuse for progression, the dialogues are well written and funny, the music is good and sets the mood nicely - but it's really all just about the balanced, fun, just-one-more-level gameplay.

It takes place in a plague colony, where the afflicted are turned into horrors controlled by a necromancer master villain. Your hero realizes she's capable of bringing herself and her allies into a halfway world, where the horrors and ultimately the villain can be fought with. While this is a simple enough premise, the way it brilliantly ties the story to the game's mechanics is one of the stellar design aspects of the game. (More on that here[www.fortressofdoors.com], if you're interested in game design).

Due to the fact that you customize the appearance of your pawns, equip them with weapons and armour, and train them towards permanent experience that you can put towards an interesting skill tree, you end up becoming more attached to them then if you just had towers" to play with. Especially your set crew of 6 archetypical towers/heroes is a fun bunch with entertaining banter in the (skippable) cut scenes
date: and by the end of the game you are genuinely interested in their actions and story decisions.\n\nI appreciated the attention to detail that allows you to customize both the difficulty and the game experience: active pause

reviewText:
A straight and forward tower defense game. If you like the genre, I very very highly recommend this game. If you don't like the genre, I doubt any game would be able to change your mind, and suggest that you carry on.

Defender's Quest managed to impress me by literally exceeding the average in every way I can think of.

+ Not a rehash of another tower defense game - it didn't really do anything extraordinary within the genre, yet I can't think of a single game I'd call it similar to.
+ Holy ♥♥♥♥, the story is actually good, the characters fun, and the funny parts actually funny.
+ There is no ultimate strategy that works for the game (build/upgrade order, etc). Each map forces a new strategy based on the availability of locations to place your characters, and enemy monster types.
+ There are dozens of maps, with 4 different difficulty settings, all of which have a New Game+ version which play differently. This game will take many dozens of hours to complete.
+ The music is good. Nothing spectacular, but for the genre and the pricetag, exceeds standards.
+ Lots of things to play with in the options menu.
+ Family friendly - I would see absolutely no problem in an 8 year old playing this game.

reviewText:
Not a good game.

It was as if the devs made sure it had all the elements to sell, but none to make it fun.

Not an enjoyable 17 hours.  I wasn't smart enough to stop.

(1)  The tower defense gameplay was poor.  The appeal of tower defense games is usually to try and optimize your defense to be efficient and effective as possible against the oncoming force.   In Defender's Quest there are very few places where your characters can be placed rationally.  In other words, there was only one strategy to place your characters when you setup.  Since there were no other real elements to the game, this made it very boring.  When you lost a mission, you couldn't try and refine your process as there was nothing to refine.  You just needed to level up to get stronger.

(2)  The character leveling up process was poor.  I decided to buy the game because the game boasted an RPG leveling-up process.  Although this is technically true, you DO HAVE TO CLICK A BUTTON in order for them to get more powerful, it could have been done automatically as your choices were thin, uncreative, and obvious.  Again, there was no game element in it.  You put the point where it was supposed to go and done.

(3)  The storyline was not worth it.  I don't remember the storyline other than it seemed shallow.  The characters were the best part of the game.  Each character seemed unique and full of personality, but the storyline needed more to take away from the poor gameplay.  Because I liked the characters and I thought they were unique, it was a big letdown to find out later that you get more characters just like them gameplay wise.  Here you thought you had a unique crazy berserker guy or a badass ice mage, but no, they are just one of many.

(4)  The enemies were uncreative.  The enemies were similar across the board.  At no point do you need to change your strategy based on the different types of enemies coming our way.    Some tower defense games have VERY uncreative enemies, but they don't need varied enemies as the game element is in the placing of the towers/characters, abilities, and tower synergy.  Defender's Quest did not have that.

reviewText:
Rating: Highly Recommended!

One of the best tower defense games I've ever played and a truly compelling role playing game as well.  The execution is almost entirely phenomenal bar some minor hiccups: overworld navigation can be a bit slow paced due to camera/view, potentially a bit too much humor at times,  and a couple sporadic difficulty spikes.  I also believe some of the new game+ features/areas shouldn't have been removed from the first playthrough, but the initial playthrough is still very engaging regardless.

The accessibility and extensive options of this game really shine and open the game to all sorts of players and styles.  There are a couple features that would make this game a bit better; Steam Workshop modification integration and maybe an expanded built in level editor.  Overall, a well-executed, deftly-plotted, and damn enjoyable experience that deserves your attention and support. Don't pass this one over without giving it a fair shot.

P.S. Still not convinced?  Try the demo and embark upon your own quest.

reviewText: Defender's Quest is a fun tower defence game infused with a little RPG element while having a strange yet humorous plot. The majority of the game isn't much of a challenge, so I would recommend this game to those who are new to this genre. However, that's not to say that avid tower defence players would not enjoy this with its strategic gameplay consisting of many unique map designs as well as the combination of old school tower abilities such as slows, critical damage and AOE effects. The RPG element in this game is very minor (you have the ability to upgrade skills and buy or find equipments) and without it, this game is your typical tower defence game. This is a great game to pick up to play for all kinds of gamers and non-gamers!

reviewText: Defender's Quest is a fantastic TD game. reviewText: While this is a decent little game, I think it fails to really deliver on its core promises. It's worth some money and time, but I wouldn't recommend paying full price for it.\n\nThe game bills itself as primarily a tower defense game. Tower defense games generally require you to come up with a strategy to defeat the enemies given a particular map and set of resources. Defender's Quest maps are much simpler, and to a large extent don't require much strategy. That's where the RPG" part comes in. There's not really any role-playing going on
date: but your characters get stronger and you can buy better weapons and armor for them. The maps don't rely so much on strategy as on having characters that are high enough level and have good enough equipment. And that generally means grinding for XP. So when it comes to the advanced and extreme levels
recommended: it's not that the levels are possible but you have to have a better strategy. The levels are simply impossible to start with
hoursPlayed: and the only way you can beat them is by leveling up your characters.\n\nIn short
voteText: it's not a good tower defense game (because the challenges rely primarily on having high-level characters not strategy)
helpfulPercent: and it's not a good RPG (because there's no real role-playing
votesHelpful: just "numbers going up" as you and the enemy gain levels and equipment). So I think it rather fails the "tactical depth" promise.\n\nThe second promise is customization
votesTotal: and it does have options to rebind all the keys and change the XP scaling
votesFunny: character names and colors
commentsCount: etc.
column16: but I don't think it's a big deal. The developer also put thought into how he could accomodate people with certain disabilities (like epilepsy)
column17: which is nice.\n\nThe third is story
column18: and I suppose that's where this game does best. The story isn't great
column19: but it does give a reason to keep playing and it is fairly humorous in some parts.\n\nTechnically
column20: the game is well-made
column21: even if it appears dated. I can't recall any bugs in the game
column22: and it has been very stable. The game runs at 800x600 resolution
column23: which is fine for me. The sound effects and music are well-done
column25: which is okay for me.\n\nI just wish the game rewarded thinking more than it rewards grinding. It's worth a try if you can get it on sale."

reviewText:
You might be forgiven for overlooking Defender's Quest. Exceedingly generic title attached to yet another tower defense game... of course, you'd be missing out on a whole lot if you let that get in the way of you playing this game.

Let me get this out of the way first: I don't like tower defense games. They usually bore me or frustrate me, and in worst case scenarios they do both at the same time. Defender's Quest deftly combines core tower defense play with RPG elements, a story that'll actually hold your attention, and beautiful artwork in and out of combat.

Say what you will about simple spritework: it looks fantastic here. Units are distinctive, animate well. I absolutely love the artwork out of combat, and the writing is fun as hell. I came to really love the cast, and was sad when it was all over- well, not for long. Game features a New Game+ option that not only ups the difficulty a ton, it gives you access to plenty of sidequests and some very powerful items if you play your cards right.

I've seen some complaints about this game lacking in depth of strategy- I don't find this to be the case, especially in maximum difficulty New Game+ battles. But one of the many wonderful things about this game is that its accessibility options allow you to tune the difficulty to your liking. Are you terrible at tower defense but want to see the storyline play out? They got you covered. Still having trouble? You can grind experience on earlier missions, too. Do you want this game to give you a merciless red-♥♥♥ beatdown and make you hate your life? Also an option! A+ to the devs for making sure the widest audience possible could enjoy their story until the very end.

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a wonderful little gem of a game that should not be ignored. Highly recommend you give it a shot- I have a pretty good feeling that almost everyone is going to find something to like here.

reviewText:

If you love tower defense

Defender's Quest is another tower defense game with a few twists that put it above the curve. For starters, rather than building soulless towers that you have zero attachment to, you employ RPG style characters to defend your Librarian." These characters can be named
date: stylized (to a slight degree with color options) and then leveled the more they're used. They each even have a system of perks that can be unlocked through the course of the campaign. You can employ as many as you can find the dosh for
recommended: but each requires "mana" to be deployed in battle. This is a finite pool that is replenished by killing baddies. The maximum mana you can have increases as your librarian levels as well
hoursPlayed: so in essence it is a clever way of keeping the player from throwing 70 towers up at the start of a new mission and steam rolling.\n\nThe game also has a pretty humorous story line

reviewText:
Both the gameplay and story are fairly good and would be able to hold their own, but together, it becomes something else. Something awesome. The whole is definately more than the sum of the two parts.


+ Well written story, very tight, no plotholes
+ Strong characters, that despite fitting into their archetypes, are not cliches
+ Suprisingly hilarious humor
+ adjustable grinding (despite grinding being a staple of RPGs, it's nice that you can skip over it)
+ useful units. No unit feels useless, they all have their part to play.
+ New Game+ has a ton of new content, both story and gameplay that can set you up for hours more

- The cut scene art takes a little getting used to


Once in game, read the directions and tips. They are actually very helpful.

This game is a great blend of tower defence and RPG. It is very easy to tailor the difficulty you will face to suit your own play style, whether you want a casual game to while away a half hour or an intense challenge that taxes your every tactical ability.

I especially love the hidden easter eggs that, if unlocked, make the second playthrough in NG+ almost a completely different game.

Well worth the price, and I will be watching any other work from this studio eagerly. Hopefully they will continue to deliver work of such a highly enjoyable standard.

reviewText:
Once you've played one or two tower defenses, you've played them all, right? YES. Well, almost completely yes.

I hate this genre with a passion. I enjoyed those first one or two tower defenses I've played, and I'm consistently disappointed with every successive iteration that there is basically no variation whatsoever, especially given how crowded the genre has been. I think it's to do with tower defenses being easy to make, in terms of design, programming, and graphics, so that a lamentably successful game can be made on a dime.

However, I do have to give this one game a recommendation. As much as I dislike the genre, this one definitely feels fresher. It blends significant RPG elements into the usual formula. Firstly, it has an engaging story, with plenty of humour and quirky characters. The levels support the story, including the occasional boss fight. Your towers" are in fact your party members
recommended: who gain experience from encounters and level up to gain additional skills
hoursPlayed: or hone their own skills further. This allows for plenty of variation amongst your party
voteText: although I found myself sticking to a single formula for each of my types.\n\nThe gameplay itself is not typical of tower defense. There's no placing your people so that they block enemies; they must be placed on the sidelines of a preset path. Also
helpfulPercent: there isn't an emphasis on placing more and more towers to increase the length of the gauntlet. Although you can place all 36 members of your party in a level
votesHelpful: doing so is generally not recommended
votesTotal: because it is far more efficient to simply upgrade the party members you have. The end result is a far more sparse tower defense game
votesFunny: one that greatly favours tactical placement
commentsCount: and consequently
column16: can be fun for the most jaded tower defense anti-fan.\n\nI also appreciated the difficulty system
column17: whereby you can choose from three difficulty settings when playing each level (and a fourth that doesn't exactly count
column18: for casual gamers). You can also come back and play the level on a higher difficulty setting
column19: with different enemy types and levels
column20: to get greater rewards (like unique items). It really added to the longevity of the game. Add in some challenges to complete
column21: and you well and truly get your $15 worth.\n\nSo
column23: I have played a tower defense that has left me wanting more! I'm keeping an eye out on Defender's Quest 2
column24: which is currently in development. If you too are as jaded as I am
column25: don't instantly discount this one. Give the demo a try."

reviewText:
Oddly one of my favorite games that I continue to go back to.  There is no mindblowing gameplay or jawdropping graphics.  What it does it does small scale, but it delights in in each area.

Story:  A very solemn themed game about war, sacrifices, dark gods, etc.  Fortunately the main cast have great (sometimes insane)  personalities and have wonderful, surprising, and often hysterical interactions.  This is where the writing really shines and is honestly probably the strongest part of the game.

Gameplay:  It's pretty standard tower defense.  Each class has skills, attack range, hit points, etc.  Set them up in likely positions and away you go.  Fail?  Try a different set up.  Characters also level up with experience for new skills, high attack, so forth.  Getting too easy? There's a Newgame+ with harder enemies and achievements that will test you.

Graphics:  During gameplay it is high quality pixel art style, detailed and well done.  Cut scenes before and after battles are...I'm not sure what to call it.  Cell shaded stop motion?  It's nice and it does the trick without being flashy.

Like I said, I just keep coming back for more, figured I might as well review it.  If you like tower defense games with interesting stories and well written characters, get this.

reviewText: One of the hidden gems of Steam right now.  Coming from a guy whose never really understood the interest people have in tower defense games, this game is just flat out fun.  The story is decent, characters are a little obnoxious but interesting, and everything about it is just so darn likable.  The combination of RGP, Stratedgy, and tower defense elements is something I personally hadn't seen done before, or at least not so well, and works better then it has any right to.  While the main game is relatively short, the amount of extra stuff to do and see in new game+ is a testament to just how much post-release work the developers have expended on this game.  Defender's Quest is an unquestionable labor of love and it really shows.  I picked this up on a the cheap during a steam sale and loved it so much I bought another for a friend and pre-ordered the sequel.\n\nIs this the best game I ever played, probably not, but was it great experience, definitely.  The games easily worth full price, but if you can get it on the cheap, I highly recommend you don't let it pass you buy.

reviewText: Well, through 6 hrs playing, my first impression is that this is a decent RPG mixing with some tower defense elements. As a tower defense game, it is too simple in strategic depth. But she doesn't. For unknown reason, she returns from the halfway to the hell. In return, the terrible experience on the verge of life and death gives her a new spiritual ability, making her capable of leading people to fight against the undead. As the game progresses, the mystery behind uncovers. This girl gradually comprehends her unavoidable destiny. She would meet many companions like warrior, archer, monk, mage and even the dragon. reviewText:
Defender's quest is a mix of a tower defense + rpg elements and the result is a very addictive game.
You're Azra royal librarian casted into the pit because you got the plague, but for some reason you get a strange vision about a golden man and discover new powers capable of destroying revenants for good, now gathering new allies you on a search trying to get out of the pit for your freedom, but also learning why you're special.
During the game you will unlock a total of 6 classes of heroes each with different pros and cons, archers low dmg but great range, knight high dmg but slow attack speed, berserker high attack speed medium dmg, ice priest area attacks with crow control skills, priest healer and buffer and dragons overally awesome.
There's a total of 30 levels each can be replayed on higher difficulties for more rewards (xp or unique gear for your defenders) but doing higher difficulties requires higher leveled defenders so they can unlock/upgrade skills and passives, unlike other TD games you upgrade the hero to give him a bonus in all stats and unlock his following active skill, which requires previously to level them up outside, kind of confusing but easy to understand as soon as you can see it.
There's a set of really hard achievements such as get 180 gold stars without buying generic heroes, reaching wave 100 on endless challenge, and killing a extremely overpowered sheep.
Once you beat the game newgame+ gets unlocked, tougher waves, newer gear, 7 side quests which some of them add a lot to the plot, journal logs after every level for more detailed lore about Azra's thoughs about everything than been happening, and items to upgrade the unique gear obtained from doing 3 star levels in normal play, can switch back and forth between both styles at will.
Highly recommended even at full price, good TD system and interesting storyline with some (a lot) of funny scenes, i even played 4 hours on a row without even realizing.

reviewText:
From indie developer Level Up Labs, Defenders Quest is a Tower Defence game set in the fantasy world of the Ash Kingdom. Hailing to the final fantasy tactics series with its strategic character placement and pixel art sprites. The unique blend of tactical RPG and Tower defence mechanics offers something familiar but fresh. With a fully customisable cast of characters and intricate levelling system, Defenders Quest is a western effort to try reinvent a diluted genre.

You play as the heroine Azra, the former royal librarian of the Ash Kingdom who is exiled to the ruinous outskirts of the city when found dying from the plague. On the brink of death, Azra awakens in a purgatory state to be attacked by a swarm of zombie like creatures or 'Revenant', and by using newly acquired magic and the assistance of a fellow surviving berserk mercenary – you journey through the Pit to uncover the secrets of these creatures and the valley. As you progress you accumulate a small army of companions of different class from swordsman, archers and dragons to face off against a number of tyrants to free the land from the plague.

The game primarily revolves around a linear story driven campaign that places you in the overworld of the pit. From here you enter battles that charge waves of enemies at you from designated points, trying to reach and attack Azra. To defeat each wave you tactically place your available units across the map using your Psi resource to do so. Each unit has unique abilities and resistances to overcome each wave. You can also recall and reposition each unit, but this consumes further Psi. Azra also has a host of abilities that can boost her own units and fend off the waves of enemies. Each battle has 3 levels of difficulty and as you progress on normal you can revisit a previous battle to gain further XP and stars.
The Overworld also acts as a hub for towns and lairs. Before battles you can visit these locations to recruit units or purchase more effective weapons and armour.
You can also complete bonus levels that offer intense challenges for greater reward after gaining enough stars.

Defenders Quest is highly accessible but introduces a depth to tower defence that elevates it requiring the player to strategize and carefully consider how each unit is levelled and their positioning in battle. The character development is clearly influenced by role playing games, whilst removing the repetition and time associated with grinding. This effectively ensures your steady progression through the story whilst each battle holds new challenges.
The narrative is also highly original and maintains intrigue and invention that is expected of a good RPG. Azra is the sympathetic protagonist facing off against an unknown villainy.
The ability to pause a battle at any time emphasises the necessity to properly prepare your units placing them in the most effective positions and levelling them appropriate to the incoming enemies.
The game aesthetic is very nostalgic, calling back to the pixel art of classic JRPGs such as Final Fantasy and Chrono Trigger. Each recruit can also have a custom name and colours, allowing you to personalise your army.
The main campaign is appropriately paced across seven acts, but encourages you to revisit past levels for bonus equipment and increased challenge. You can complete your army with any class of your choice as their unlocked, further increasing the range of tactics when battling and tailoring your strategies the units you've selected.


The breadth and uniqueness of the story is commendable and gives engrossing context to the battles. However the static cut-scenes through which its told at times become unnecessarily prolonged and tedious, after the initial character introductions we generally skipped through them to get to the battles.
Furthermore there is a distinct characterised design to the figures in these scenes which drastically differs to the more befitting pixel models. This lack of consistency is also noticeable against the painterly backdrops.
Defenders Quest is strongly reminiscent of its influences, but also tries to introduce a more detailed textured interpretation of its characters, that unfortunately leaves to big a void in the games overall presentation.

What starts out as a charming and casual game soon evolves into a challenge.
Unlike most tower defence games there is no such thing as the ultimate deployment to beat every level. Each battle requires a unique strategy, that sometimes requires you to fine tune each unit.

Whilst tower defence remains primarily a casual genre, Level up Labs have crafted a game with a refined battle system and immersive world that requires a fair investment of the players time. Through adapting existing RPG conventions and introducing a few new parameters, Defenders Quest's perilous journey is worthy of the most battle-hardened players.

Watch at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KVFiflbRco

reviewText:
This game never had me hooked but never lost my interest either. The story was meh and there were far too many dialogue cut scenes (you can skip those). You progress your way across a world map, dotted with battles. As you progress you meet new characters and unlock new classes. Archers, dragons, swordsman, ice mages. There are skill trees for each class.

Each battle consists of placing your characters in static positions to defend against waves of enemies that spawn on various lanes. It's pretty standard tower defense stuff. Certain classes do better against certain enemies. As you kill enemies you reclaim IP which can be used to boost characters and increase their powers for the rest of the battle. Nothing spectacular. I did appreciate the time controls so I could speed up 4x or slow down to 1/2 time as needed.

The problem comes when you encounter a difficult level you can't win. At that point you must go back to previous battles you've already won and play it on a higher difficulty. This yields scrap (basically money) and XP, sometimes a unique weapon. You'll have to do this a lot. Unfortunately it gets tedious after a while.

It was an interesting concept and I did manage to finish the game. But honestly I wish it wasn't so repetitive.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Both the gameplay and story are fairly good and would be able to hold their own, but together, it becomes something else. Something awesome. The whole is definately more than the sum of the two parts.


+ Well written story, very tight, no plotholes
+ Strong characters, that despite fitting into their archetypes, are not cliches
+ Suprisingly hilarious humor
+ adjustable grinding (despite grinding being a staple of RPGs, it's nice that you can skip over it)
+ useful units. No unit feels useless, they all have their part to play.
+ New Game+ has a ton of new content, both story and gameplay that can set you up for hours more

- The cut scene art takes a little getting used to


Once in game, read the directions and tips. They are actually very helpful.

reviewText:
This game is a great blend of tower defence and RPG. It is very easy to tailor the difficulty you will face to suit your own play style, whether you want a casual game to while away a half hour or an intense challenge that taxes your every tactical ability.

I especially love the hidden easter eggs that, if unlocked, make the second playthrough in NG+ almost a completely different game.

Well worth the price, and I will be watching any other work from this studio eagerly. Hopefully they will continue to deliver work of such a highly enjoyable standard.

reviewText: I've thoroughly enjoyed Defender's Quest, it's just a Tower Defence game, but with an awesome story, great characters and challenging gameplay, what's more there is enough hidden away to keep you coming back for more, going for the 100%, collecting weapons and armour, the challenge modes and if you truly hate yourself and enjoy cryptic crosswords the Secret Book.\n\nWhat's more, there is a New Game+ that not only increases the challenge but adds new levels, new lore etc.  All in all a well thought out game to pass the time, and will have you laughing out loud at the story, and cursing as you go for the perfects.

reviewText: Don't be turned off by the graphics of this game.  It really is something special.  It's lane defense, pure and simple, but it does this so well, making it an rpg where all your towers can level up and improve through skill trees unique to them.  The graphics are a bit primitive, and the story cut scenes might turn some people off, but give it a chance.  The story is what sold me, as it's incredibly funny without having to go through the self aware brand of humor.  It's just really well written, with great jokes and comedic timing.  The gameplay is very satisfying and there's a lot of things to do, thanks to new game plus and challenge modes.  You can even tweak how fast your characters level in order to speed your game along.  I cannot recommend this enough because it's just fun and gives you so many options for play.  There's even an option to increase game speed to make those usually slow lane defense games super fast, for either convenience or increased difficulty.  Wonderful little title.

reviewText:
An excellent tower defense game that's very fun to play. The story is engrossing and well written and it has a nice difficulty curve. It also sports the best new game + modes I've ever played. I plan to buy the sequel to this day 1, and I plan to play the awesome free HD update that this game is getting from beggining to end.

I'm hard pressed to think of any part about this game I didn't like. It can be a bit grindy but that's only if you decide you want to try to beat all of the difficulties in 1 sitting. For those of you who like to slap a game into hardmode from the getgo I guess I'd advise you to stay away because hard mode will kick you in the nuts, light you on fire, and then throw you out the window unless your characters are ready for it.

Great game from an awesome indie dev team. Well worth your time and money.

reviewText:
I usually prefer to wait until I finish a game before I review it (barring episodic games but even then I finish the episodes that are available THEN review) but I enjoyed this game so much I figured I'd might as well review even before I finished it -- especially since it seems like there's so much to do!

First of all, I'm not normally a tower defense fan; I actually picked up Defender's Quest as part of a Humble Bundle female protagonists deal. I don't even remember why I decided to try the game on a whim but I'm SO glad I did. The story is interesting and, even better, funny. There's tons of really good characters and the devs have done a good job of creating a story that walks the line between silly and serious pretty well.

In terms of the gameplay, like I said -- I don't particularly enjoy tower defense, mostly because the ones I've played previous to this have all seemed far too complicated to be worth the time and effort. Prior to Defender's Quest, the game that I've enjoyed the most in the genre was Plants vs. Zombies. Defender's Quest is a step above that, really, because DQ actually attempts to have a story and character development, though the basic goals of the two games are the same. I'd say DQ is a little bit tougher than PvZ, if only because there's a lot more variability in the maps, whereas PvQ was a fairly straight-forward flat plain. DQ offers maps with multiple enemy spawn points (three is the most I've seen so far), different terrain (e.g., water vs. land), and various restrictions in routes for enemies (and placement for allies). I especially enjoyed the way you can change battle speed to slow down -- or pause -- the enemies spawning to catch up or speed up (4X is amazing) if you're sure your allies can handle the enemies without much management. It's a nice mix that I liked, because I prefer to micro-manage at the start, rather than during the battle. Even better is the different battle difficulty settings, so you can go back and replay battles on a harder setting (same map, different enemies) PLUS bonus challenges and (so the achievements would suggest) a new game plus mode -- means there's tons of stuff to do. Playing DQ actually makes me want to go out and find similar tower  defense games to play because I enjoyed this one so much -- which is probably the best compliment I can give a game!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A good game, I'm not as crazy over as it people to seem to be but I liked it. Personally I think it was a bit too grindy if you're not setting EXP to a higer precentage than default. The writing is also decent in a fun way. Overall worth it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is quite a treat. I love its art style and combat mechanics. Its a refreashing take on the Tower defense genre with some fun rpg elements mixed in. You name you heros, level them, and find new equipment for them. Then these heros are used in a tower defense acting in place of the towers. The combat is like Final Fantasy Crystal Defenders.

The conversations are quite amusing and the story thus far has been pretty entertaining and is keeping me hooked and wanting to learn more. I also love puns so this game gets points there.

There are two big complaints I have for the title though. The biggest is that you have to run it at a fixed resolution in windowed mode. The window is so small it could very well fit on an 8 tablet. This means playing for an extended period will likely hurt your eyes. I really wish I could make the game bigger without having to use fullscreen. The second complaint is the sound. It gets very bad when you have a healer and ice hero on the field. Especially a 4x speed. I would recommend turning the sound off and either listening to the in game music or playing your own. There is not voice acting so you wont be missing anything."
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a person who started his TD career in WC2/SC i'd say this is some of the most fun I have had playing a tower defense game. Instead of using Towers you call forth allies to your astral plane (Current Map) to help defend yourself from Revenent's (The bad guys).

There are several different Allies to choose from and each ally can be specifically tailored for any given purpose. There is a suprising amount of depth involved in deciding where to place your unused talent points. Each character is Namable and has cosmetic customizable options. Naming a Character after yourself makes you want to use that character which is alot of fun to role play. If your into that sort of thing.The town's have places to recruit new allies and buy new weapon and armor.

The map plays out alot like Mario World or the equivalent and you can go back and beat older levels on harder diff's to get better gear and level. There is also a storyline written by some type of Wrinting/English major and the writing isn't too terrible. Some if it will give you a laugh and some will just make you scratch your head. But all in all this game is a lot of fun and is definitely worth the little money asked.

-Casey

reviewText:
I bought this one because I remember playing it as a website's free flash game and I had very good memories of it.

This game makes a perfect mix between Tower Defense (something I love) and RPG (which is a 'meh' to me). Defender's Quest may look like a 10 minutes casual game but it's not. It has an incredibly long story and it's full of challenges. You have a great control over difficulty in this game as each stage has 4 levels of difficulty, which also makes this game very replayable, as you'll need future gained strength to beat the 4th level of past stages.

Despite of my lack of interest in RPG, the mix with Tower Defense is so good and balanced that I really enjoyed that part. You can have your very own and custom gameplay, as you plan your own team, choose how they evolve and choose the gear they equip.

Defender's Quest is a great tactical game, it gives you a lot of freedom to test different strategies and it can give you different gameplay experiences based on your own choices and it doesn't get repetitive, something that is easily found in any other Tower Defense game.

Gonchito approves this! (Yeah, I'm so great that I speak about me in third person).

reviewText:
This is a great tower defense game with lots or RPG elements included.  Instead of towers, you have heroes you position along a path to defend your leader.  As these heroes fight, they level up and can be built into different styles of tower depending on the skills you take.

Pros
- Lots of good tower defense gameplay
- Lots of well done RPG elements so you can modify each hero and personalize your play style
- Good story and interesting characters
- Lots of great items to equip to make your heroes (towers) even more effective
- The game rewards replay of older levels on higher difficulties by giving your heroes (towers) more experience and the ability to unlock special items
- Lots of replay value with all the difficulty levels and all the things that can be unlocked.
- Challenging maps that sometimes require you to think outside your normal setups.

Cons
- Older graphics
- Gameplay can be repetative if you're just interested in the story

Overall this is a great game that I would highly recommend to an RPG or tower defense enthusiast. The game gives you the option of both relaxed gameplay and very challening maps if you want them.  (It also rewards your party for completing said maps.)

reviewText:
If you love tower defence game, you will not regret picking this one up.
So ok yes it only has fixed path maps, but it just does them so well, and with the character skill trees it really does vary it up just enough. The game does have a few problems imo but honestly I didnt even really notice them till I was well into new game + cause I was having such a great time with it.

So yes the skill trees could have been mapped diffrently, yes there could have been more map variety, yes weapons & armor were really really vanilla, yes there was soooooo much room for spell variety, yes there was so much more dialog and story your left wanting in the end. But in spite of these flaws the game completly shines over them. And to me did it in an endearing, charming way that really made me fall in love with it. It really left me just wanting more of it (which made me squee when I heard there making a DQ2)

But at $15 us it would have been worth every penny, let alone the $5 I got it for. I just cant recomend this one enough for td fans. I will even go so far as to say its a must have for td buffs.

reviewText:
This is a tower defense/RPG hybrid where your towers and home base are all characters that level up between battles, giving you points to spend on stats and extra abilities. No tower mazing is involved, and there are enemies that can attack your towers, necessitating armor, dodge, and healing abilities in addition to strong damage output, slowing attacks, buffs, debuffs, and knockback. Defender's Quest succeeds in blending tower defense and RPG gameplay thanks to strong design on many levels.

pros:
+ core gameplay is fun -- character and enemy design are good and placing/upgrading your characters always feels strategic
+ excellent balance and tuning with multiple difficulty settings
+ the interface is intuitive and well-designed
+ there is a good amount of content in the game
+ graphics may not be fancy, but they're attractive enough and nothing is an eyesore
+ good soundtrack and SFX, although more length and variety in level music would be nice
+ somewhat engaging but not overly distracting story with effective world-building

cons:
- weak customization: although there are many global spells and character upgrades to choose from, there's rarely more than one viable choice for top effectiveness.
- the comedy in the game, while quite funny in its own right, is very silly and can clash with the dramatic aspects of the writing, hurting immersion and undercutting character development (looking at you Slak)

Overall, this game is a real gem and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: A Diamond in the rough.  Out of all the crap games here on Steam, that look good & look promising...this game actualy delivers.  One of the rare gems of a game that gives you exactly what you would want & hope for from a game like this.\n\nCombining the tower defense & RPG qualities is done perfectly with a fairly balanced level up system & an excellent & fairly deep story line that gets you interested in the characters & the story & gives you hours & hours of tower defense + RPG goodness. reviewText:
Never thought RPG and Tower defence genre could have a great cross-bred like this!

Like any other TD games out there, your main mission is prevent any enimies from reaching the party leader standing at the end of the road. The horde which is consist of a few types of zombies, slug-like creatures,... keeps coming in pre-defined routes. In fact, there's nothing quite unique in the mechanic of TD in this game.

However, the true gem lies in the RPG aspect of the game. What's a TD game without towers? Nah, your towers now are replaced by class-based characters ranging from a psychopath to a cute dragon. Many elements of RPG genre are brought into the game like skill tree, equipments and again, classes. Trouble with fast moving creeps, you have an Ice Mage to counter, or facing heavy armor zombies with the might of a Paladin.

Not every maps are so hard, but you still need to grind a little for exp and especially epic items. (well, not really that epic but atleast they have purple titles)

To be honest, you can't expect a long and heart-touching story with dozens of play time for such a small game like this, but for almost 3 hours so far I'm quite satisfied.

Finally, thanks jatan11t/GAR for this lovely gift :)

reviewText: Defender's Quest starts off as a pretty simple tower defence game with a goofy fantasy story and basic presentation, but then you start getting deeper into the game, unlock all the character classes and upgrade your characters more, and you find that there is actually a ton of depth and playability here. What's more, it never loses its intuitive and elegant design as it becomes more mechanically complex, and the game does a fine job of presenting you with a tough challenge but essentially giving you all the tools you need to overcome said challenge. Success is not determined simply by grinding to level up your characters, but rather by finding a way to better manage your resources until you find the optimal way to succeed.\n\nThis was one of my sleeper hits from 2013, and it's one of my favourite tower defence games on Steam, up there with Defence Grid: The Awakening and Plants vs. Zombies. It's a great starter tower defence game and introduces less experienced players to its mechanics in a very manageable way, but it also provides the depth and strategy that you just won't get from most of the free flash-based TD games you can find online. It's a fresh take on the genre and its very well executed...just don't expect to be too engaged by the cutscenes and character interactions that break up the combat missions. They're occasionally funny, but often rote and unnecessarily long. But that's just about my only criticism of the game - everything else is rock-solid.

It adds another layer of depth outside of the TD with progression and can be a difficult game but very rewarding in the end. If you are a fan of TDs especially wc3 ones, definitely tell you to give this one a try.  The only thing is your character is always a girl so there isnt anything you can do about it.

reviewText: This game is a brilliant tower defense game. You take a very active role in upgrading towers/people and using active powers. There is a robust upgrade system for your hero and each type of tower/role. The game has an EXCELLENT story with unusually distinct and interesting characters. As for longevity, there is a new game+ mode that adds new side quests involving a completely new story line! There is plenty of incentive to go back and replay levels at harder difficulties because the rewards are improved and there are different enemies, which can drastically change how a level plays. Seriously, this game is great value at full price and a steal if you ever see it on sale. If you like this genre, just buy it already!
