reviewText:
You play as  Azra, a librarian who's been plague-infected and thus thrown into  the Pit. This deep and vast place was supposed to be her graveyard but instead, on the brink of death she learns of her new powers and purpose.

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten  is a tower defense mixed with RPG elements. It features a decent story spiced with funny dialogues between party members (unfortunately not voice acted). There's quite a few maps and the new game+ along with endless mode brings a whole lot of content to the table. It's also worth noting that the game gets really, really hard towards the end of the ng+ playthrough even with end game gear and abilities.

Highly recommended for those that enjoy tower defenses.

reviewText:
I wrote a review for this about a year or so ago but thought I'd rewrite it as I have some different and new views on the game.

First off, this is a tower defense game that revolves around a well written story with a nicely done narrative that includes all the who/what/when/where/why questions, along with moments of subtle humor and despair. On the first play through you get all the character dialogue that propels the story but not a whole lot more. On the second play through you get the main character's (Azra unless otherwise named) thoughts after each mission is completed. These journal entries go pretty in-depth for being subtext you don't even need to go through. There are some 30 entries and I do recommend reading them.

The game starts with the Azra wondering where the hell she is and finding the first warrior, Slak, entering into a battle against the Revenant (dead). The story progresses and you will find all the other characters (read 'towers'). There are six others you find and you can have up to six of them in that class, in total allowing you to have an army of 36 towers and Azra.

The Berserker is a hack 'n' slash guy. He wields a sword, wears no shirt, and thirsts for blood.
The Ranger is your snarky and quick witted bow expert. She often griefs Azra on menial things such as, not being pretty enough to have her plans work out."
The Healer comes off as overprotective and cautious but holds the team together.
The Ice Mage is cold and has cynical tendencies but wields the power to stop hordes of foes.
The Knight is rightous and pledges himself to Azra. He takes down the strongest enemies by ripping them of their armor.
The Dragon is the last to join the group. She acts like a god and thinks the humans beneath her yet is impressed at how far Azra and her companions have traveled thus far. She also enjoys eating sheep.

With these characters you can create varying strategies on every battlefield in the game. Some will require a near exact positioning that you'll figure out by trial and error
date: while others are more liberal in placement. You can pull off a ton of combos though and it's cool to find something that synergizes well.\n\nNow
hoursPlayed: each has a skill branch (not tree since there are only two directions it goes) and with each level you get one point to put in each skill slot. Most of them are damage boosts for their attack tier (each character has a five tier attack that is upgraded through Psi that is earned by killing enemies in the level) and the rest are passive buffs. They can include skill cooldowns
voteText: range
helpfulPercent: crit/poison/bleed/blind/armor piercing chance
votesHelpful: slow/stun/burn
votesTotal: group damage amplifiers and tagging enemies so they take more damage.\n\nAzra also has six spells she can upgrade. There are three damage and three buff spells. A direct lightning attack
votesFunny: an area of effect crystal explosion
commentsCount: and a full screen flame attack. The buffs are sending your characters into a frenzy to increase attack speed
column16: massive healing
column17: and pushing back waves of enemies. There are also unlockable spell books that can be equipped to provide boosts.\n\nThere are three weapons in game that two classes can use. Swords for the Berserker and Knight
column18: a bow for the Ranger
column19: and staffs for the Healer and Ice Mage. Progressing through the story increases the price and damage of future weapons. Armor can be equipped to them as well
column20: heavy and light variants.\n\nThe max level each member can achieve is 60 so you won't be able to max every skill on each character. The good thing about having multiple in a class means that you can have someone with a high bleed chance
column21:
and give the other person the higher armor piercing chance. At any point you can pay a small fee of scrap (currency) to respec their builds.

So that's the gist of the game. Pretty straight forward. Where things really get rolling are on the new game +. Much more challenging and rewarding. A new currency of "skulls" becomes used to upgrade the special weapons and armors you aquire through missions. It's pretty hard to get all the skulls as you'll need to grind to get your characters to a high enough level to beat the much harder than before levels. There are also a few puzzles hidden here and there that you need to keep an eye out for. I had some trouble with it and found a guide and without it there would've never been a way I'd have caught on.

All in all

reviewText:
I forgot I had this game and I am ashamed that I forgot I had it. I had a lot of fun playing this before, as I did just now, but it is late. I feel it deserves my thumbs up. I'll tell ya why.

You are a lady who finds people to join you and help out as the story progresses. The story is quite nice. The people are funny and will often make jokes and claim that they hate the hero, when really they don't.

The actual gameplay itself is typical of most tower defense. You have a grid where you place your units (the 'people' that joined you), and they fight when something is near. What I like about this game is that the different types of units work together. I won't go into any detail about this because you'll probably want to experience it yourself.

Each level is split up into four difficulties. So if you're feeling brave, you can try the hardest. Even if you fail your units will still gain experience points. If you're feeling like a wuss, try the casual setting.

The units have skill trees which you apply 1 point on each level up. I find this to be very rewarding, although sometimes when you complete a level you may have to apply a buncha points (I had to apply about 20 before after one level). C'est la vie.

It is well worth the whatever I paid for it. I don't remember buying it, but I am very glad I did. You'll not be disappointed if you're a fan of tower defense games with a hint of humour and a nice storyline.

reviewText:
Pretty decent tower defence, interesting story, and i enjoy the semi-persistant character/tower concept.
The resolution is a bit funky, but it does adress it to a degree. Keys a re rebindable, both by several presets or do-it-yourself.
Progression looks fairly balanced, though you will on occasion need to replay a previous level to buff up.
I haven't delved into the workshop content yet, but that was an unexpected and welcome addition.
I'd definately recommend it, and it appears they are working on a second one with a whole new story/world. keepin an eye out for that~

Counter review to all the fanboy hype for this game, as I just bought it on sale since it looked good and I needed something to play on my mac book.

This is JUST any other tower defense game. Because every tower defence game has its own unique mechanics for upgrades. The only thing this game blends" is RPG lore/tropes into tower defense as a theme. This is done in that you upgrade individual towers and each tower levels up on its own. That's it. The blend is just graphical
date: and it does that poorly because the graphics are poorly done. I don't want to be harsh because I want to give the indie devs the benefit of the doubt in that they couldn't aquire funding/talent for aethistics
recommended: but this is worse than a free flash game I could have played instead. Another problem which just elludes to really ameature/cheap UI development is that the game cannot go into fullscreen correctly. It just remains at 800x600 and the fullscreen option simply draws a giant black box on your monitor and centers teh 800x600 game. Why couldn't they have actually developed the UI before releasing it...? Not really a pleasing game to play

reviewText:
A fun little tower defense with RPG elements. The protagonist is a librarian cast into a plague colony, and sets out on a quest to escape. She quickly discovers latent supernatural powers that allow others to defeat the zombified infected. She serves as the objective that must be defended. Besides the standard ability to summon units to defend her, she's also capable of casting spells for harming or buffing, and can equip spell books to further enhance her abilities.

Throughout the game you'll encounter characters who join with you, unlocking new classes of characters (berserker, archer, healer, etc.) that you can hire and summon to defend you. The classes come with simple skill trees that unlock new abilities or enhance them in some way, and every individual unit can be leveled differently from the other, enabling a more diverse army to choose from.

The game is made for a wide variety of skill levels. New players and seasoned veterans alike will find something to challenge them when the game gets rolling, and you can replay maps as you please for practice or for XP/money. The map's rewards are better for higher difficulty settings, and can reward unique equipment for success. The game can seem like a grindfest, but the devs wisely included the option to increase XP/money gains and to ensure all units get equal access to it, regardless of whether or not they entered battle.

The story itself is very competent. The characters are largely likeable and the writing and humor is enjoyable. The cast tend to have something of an emphasis on their quirks, but mostly avoid becoming bland one notes with varying degrees of depth.

The game is not without its flaws. Completionists can find that the New Game+ might become something of a chore, the skill trees are rather simple in their execution, and certain parts of the story or characters can become tiresome (looking at you, Slak). If you can put this aside, you still have a fun and funny game that's worth a look. Grab the demo and give it a spin. You can even transfer your save file if you choose to purchase it, and the game is set to receive an HD update (at the time of writing) and sequel.

reviewText:
Highly recommended.

This is a great game. I put about 200 hours into this. If you enjoy defense strategy like Defense Grid or Orcs Must Die then this is for you. It seems easy at first but it becomes more difficult as you play. You will receive a true challenge on the very hard and the newgame+ levels.

What I liked most about this game is that you can play the game relaxed or increase the difficulty for a real challenge. The storyline is decent and keeps you engaged.

If you find yourself in a challenging spot for newgame+, I would encourage researching level up and placement ideas. Lots of fun and well worth the $$.

I will be purchasing the next release.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying one thing: I don’t like TDs. Too many of them revolve around mechanics I consider boring, such as interest, and generally, they don’t offer much beyond the core, basic gameplay expected from the genre. With that out of the way, I’ll try to explain how Defender’s Quest won me over.

It’s impossible not to mention the fantastic writing present in the game: The story is overall serious, but the script makes no commitment to sounding mature or gritty. To the contrary: while some may argue the cast is composed of very standard archetypes, it’s still highly varied, and the humorous exchanges between the characters are a joy to see. Ironically, it’s their likability that makes the story much easier to care about, not presentation or “visceral” experiences. Take notes, games industry.

While I’m at it, the soundtrack is also a very strong point, and is included in the game’s folder for free. Plot and music are hardly all the game has to offer, though. As I said, I don’t like TDs and what impresses me the most about Defender’s Quest is how it carefully avoids annoying mechanics I’ve come to associate with the genre.

In this game, you don’t have to worry about insane resource management (interest) or fast finger movement (since you can pause mid-wave). It’s only about character loadout and positioning. That doesn’t mean it’s easy, but that it’s the right kind of hard. That it offers depth.

Going through the game should take you about five hours, but that can increase tenfold if you try to finish all level variations and challenges. For me, it clocked at just over sixty hours, and was definitely worth its price. I can recommend it to anyone looking for a twist on the traditional TD formula.

reviewText:
Never expected this much from this game.



As usual I logged on Steam and found this on sale with just 1.49 USD.
Looking at the screenshots it seems like it has some RPG-maker graphics and it is a tower defense game.
Man I am really not a fan of tower defense but after scrolling down the review section I see a lot of thumbs up; so I decided to give it a try.

And it sucks.... ME IN!

The game plays like traditional tower defense, with RPG elements like levelling up, buying armour and upgrading skills.
This gives a feeling of progression since in more traditional tower defense game its all about strategy. Every battle is a new battle, nothing carries on to the next level.

In this game, your heros are permanent allies. You recruit them from towns, form your own little army and grow them accordingly to your preference.

Story wise its ok and the dialogues are funny at times. The presentation of the whole game is quite neat and easy on the eyes so you dont get alot of useless stuff displaying to you.

There seems to be quite alot of levels as well as a new game plus where you get unique stuff and enemies which adds replayable value.

The only downside is that it seems the skill tree could get some more diversity. Like it would be awesome if a standard warrior can have different styles or something.

But all in all this is a solid game and is definitely worth grabbing during this 1.49 USD sale. The fun far exceeds the cost. But if you missed the sale and it goes back to 14.99, I would recommend you to think twice before buying.

reviewText: Tower Defense meets RPG, for real.\nMany games try to combine different genres yet few does as good a job as Defender's Quest. If you like Tower Defense games and are looking for something new to mix up what is becoming a stale and tired formula, this game is right up your alley. While allowing you to build your characters in the way that you want, customizing your 'towers' becomes a pleasure rather than a chore. The clever use of characters to perform as your towers is a fun way to almost get to know the defenders that you're using, and the story, something that most tower defense games shirk is actually quite amusing. Give it a try if you're wondering what it is about, this game delivers a lot of bang for your buck, offering hours and hours of replayability. The New Game+ feature completely mixes up the challenges so that even when you beat the game you're just getting started.

reviewText:
I bought this game before it was greenlit after seeing a WTF is... about it. Played it start to end twice in a row and had a blast all the way thru.

For those uninitialized: Defender's Quest is a Tower defense with heavy RPG elements. Your towers" are characters you recruit thru progress of the game. You level them up and give them skillpoints and equip them with weapons and armors. Your characters will be with you the entire playthru and level up with your character.

The goal per usual is to stop the enemies from reaching your "pool" and taking away from your life. This is done thru set mazes where the monsters have to follow a premade maze
recommended: no mazing for you that like to build your own mazes in TDs. You progress thru a gameworld where you can face each stage in three various difficulties
hoursPlayed:
the harder it is the better the reward. You can also backtrack to previously defeated levels to try it on a harder level or just grind for gold/xp for your characters.

The game also offers a fairly interesting story with alot of written dialogue with some pretty nice graphics to go along. The steam version also features updated graphics to the game which makes the game feel apropiate for the pricetag.

A must have for lovers of classic Tower Defense games with a twist and interesting new mechanics."
voteText: December 3, 2013

reviewText:
As far as tower defense games go, I normally play them a little bit and then grow board of them. That was not the case with Defender's Quest. I've found myself unknowingly playing for hours. As with all TD games, you raise your heroes, while managing your resources. After battle, you gain EXP which levels your heroes up and scrap (gold) to buy equipment to make them even stronger.

You can easily choose to play with an army (up to 6 of each hero) or you can play with only the main hero from each class for an extra challenge. For those who dislike grinding for exp and gold, you will be pleased to know they have included an option to boost the exp and gold gain by 300%.

I highly suggest this game if you enjoy TD games.

reviewText:
Pretty fun game at a sweet deal of one fitty.

Tactical tower defense game with some rpg aspects to it. Storyline is pretty good, some characters are pretty humorous and enjoyable.

It does get hard, being an avid tower defense player back a few years, I thought this would be cake, but was I wrong. There a few challenging levels and a few buggy-glitch levels. If you see a hand in one of the levels, you can't kill it (I think).

Aside from a few small bugs that you can beat by utterly destroying the level, this is a solid game.

9/10 would play again.

reviewText: Though I may not be one to play many tower defense games, this one has really grasped my attention. At first glance, it may look like a bit of a low graphic, and average drawn out sprites/characters, but that's not where the game is supposed to shine. Even the, the story is surprisingly detailed, and you learn to appreciate the characters. Where it shines most is the gameplay itself! A great game to have in windowed mode while doing other things, it's a pleasant distraction, very refreshing, and easy to learn. There is a ton of depth with characters having their own skill trees, each defensive unit becoming special in their own way. It has good areas to level up quickly if you want to power up, but it doesn't feel necessary. In fact, the game has a good pace, and you could pick it up and play just a few minutes, or a few hours! The ability to slow down, pause, or speed up combat is so pleasing to have also, allowing me to follow a flow I'm comfortable with, never too pressured, but always leaving you thinking. I highly recommend it for the price, and tower defense lover would enjoy this, and even those new or not keen on the genre will feel comfortable with it. I know I was!

reviewText:
Let me premise by saying that I'm a fan of Tower Defense game and purchased this game at 90% off for a grand total of $1.49, as such, this game was an absolute steal!

The game feels well paced, making sure you have the ability to beat the next level with adequate skill, but rewards you for taking the time to perfect a level. If you're looking for a deeper challenge, you can replay earlier levels at a higher difficulty, or if you're feeling stuck or underpowered you have the option to go back a few levels until you're prepared to advance.

The actual game itself revolves around a band of characters replete with customizable appearances, skills, invetory, and a set base class that allows for a wide variety of playstyles and setups. The actual mechanics of the game are designed to allow you to either place your towers (units) down and work from there, or micromanage them for greater effect. As you progress you'll be unlocking spells to engage you further and allow for more in depth strategy.

That all being said, I find myself falling most in love with the games charming and quirky characters that really sell the rather contrived story. Through the course of the game you'll meet a wide variety of personalites that play off of each other with a dry sense of humor and extremely comedic results. They each feel consistant and defined, and it's always a pleasure to see how they interact when they're not dealing with the plot. Even the main character has witty dialogue and interplay with the party, making you feel legitimately connected to people who are essentially stationary sources of damage in the actual game.

The only point that could be held against it is the fact that the graphics and art style feel 'cheap'. The world map and actual gameplay is set in the old sprite style that we've all seen for the past few decades, and it makes the game feel dated. When you're watching the games cutscenes, you're stuck looking at a few stationary characters that look like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ combination of paper cutouts and Protector characters. It's nice that they took the time to set up full cutscenes and dialogue, but the graphics just aren't there.

As it stands, I'd say that this game is a real gem. On sale for 90% I'd say 'buy it' every time no matter who you are. If you find it on sale for anything over 25%, at least give it a good look, hopefully you'll like what you see. For the full price of $15, it's still a great game for fans of the genre.

reviewText: Are you looking for an old school RPG mixed with tower defence? ... No?... well you should because this game is awesome! Witty story mixed with fun combat, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten will be the cause of taking you away from socialising for many hours. reviewText:
When I bought this game, I expected I was getting a mediocre game that would help me pass the time while I looked for other, more interesting games to play.  It turns out that the videos on the store page somehow make the game look a less interesting than it actually is.

There's something quite satisfying about surveying each level, and positioning your troops such that different types of troops are in positions that allow them to function as efficiently as possible.  It's fun to get progressively better at optimizing what your (growing) set of troops can do.

The second playthrough was a little less interesting.  You're left with either choosing to grind for experience for your troops, or to turn up the experience multiplier (which feels like cheating to me), so I can't say there's much replay value.  However, that shouldn't stop you from buying the game and playing through once, if you're so inclined.

7.5/10.

reviewText: Hands down one of the most fun tower defense games i have played, the rpg element to it isn't too complex but its plenty enough to keep you playing and doing old missions to level up and earn scraps which is the money inside the game, which eventually becomes a non-factor if you play a mission more then once for each one, but if you just blow through the game things will be much more difficult as is any rpg game. The game stays challenging throughout the entire game with choosing 2-3star diffculities for each mission, and boss encounters on higher difficulties can be gruesome, unless of course you out level it.\n\nI have no complaints, aside from wishing there was dlc for more content, but i hear they are in the process of making a sequel so i am excited for that.

reviewText: Buy this game now.  It's an extremely solid indie title that can prove quite addicting.\n\nIn addition, t's the first game I've ever played that made grinding levels fun (and I HATE grinding in video games).  Mostly this is because going back to old areas on harder difficulties means you'll be fighting different monsters, so oftentimes you'll have to drastically change your strategy to beat the same stage.  On top of that, the difficulty can be finely tuned according to your tastes and playstyle (Want faster/slower xp gains?  Less/more penalties for failing?) WHILE you're playing the game, so the game never gets boring or feels frustratingly hard.

reviewText:
When I bought this game, I expected I was getting a mediocre game that would help me pass the time while I looked for other, more interesting games to play.  It turns out that the videos on the store page somehow make the game look a less interesting than it actually is.

There's something quite satisfying about surveying each level, and positioning your troops such that different types of troops are in positions that allow them to function as efficiently as possible.  It's fun to get progressively better at optimizing what your (growing) set of troops can do.

The second playthrough was a little less interesting.  You're left with either choosing to grind for experience for your troops, or to turn up the experience multiplier (which feels like cheating to me), so I can't say there's much replay value.  However, that shouldn't stop you from buying the game and playing through once, if you're so inclined.

7.5/10.

reviewText: An excellent tower defense game that is traditional in all the ways I love but innovative where it counts. Instead of placing towers, you're placing party members. Like a traditional TD game, there are resource points you acquire within a round that you can spend on placing new towers (i.e. allies) or buffing the towers you've already placed. In Defender's Quest, this resource is called PSI"
date: which is essentially the "mana" of Azra (aka: you
hoursPlayed: Defender's Quest also gives you two other resources to spend BETWEEN rounds: gold and experience.\n\nExperience is used to unlock abilities on an ally's skill tree
voteText: thereby making them available to use in battle. (Each skill is assigned a power level and is not available in battle until you buff this ally to that level using PSI points.)\n\nGold is used to hire new allies into the party or to purchase armor/weapon upgrades for individual allies
helpfulPercent: which immediately and permanently boosts their stats (i.e. unlike skill upgrades
votesHelpful: these are conferred immediately at the start of battle---no PSI points required.)\n\nEvery level can be replayed as many times as you want to farm XP and gold
votesTotal: and every level has multiple difficulty settings that earn you better gold/XP rewards for beating them. (There is no penalty for running away.) Beating the highest difficulty on some levels earns you a legendary weapon or armor
votesFunny: far more powerful than anything you'll find in shops.\n\nThe only bad thing I could possibly say about the game is that the art in the cutscenes makes the game's aesthetic somewhat comparable to something you'd find on a flash portal. By flash portal standards
commentsCount: the artwork is amazing. By overall industry standards
column16: the art seems a little amateur. The in-game art is pixely and SNES-tastic. I criticize only the cutscene art here. But in the end
column17: it doesn't even really matter
column18: because the cutscenes have no effect on gameplay
column19: and you can even skip over them all if you like. The game itself is A+.\n\nIf you like Tower Defense
column20: it's one of the better TD games in the Steam catalogue."

reviewText:
At first I was not 100% sure about buying or passing mostly owing to the simple art style and the fact its a tower defense which are a dime a dozen now days, however after looking at reviews and seeing some high praise and checking the forms and seeing active Dev's interacting with the community decided to give it a try.

The first thing I met was a user agreement which is fairly common now days however unlike others I actually read it was very simple and easy to understand made a nice impression and told me about their attention to detail before even accessing the first screen of the game, this attention to detail was further proven once within the game the customization in just the options menu alone warrants this game being noticeable, I can't say if you will find it worth your money but if you have a few bucks burning a hole in your pocket or see this on sale (well worth full price in my opinion) grab it.

This game and its Developers are like a Unicorn in this day and age they clearly care about their players and the product itself Will be keeping a eye out for future releases from them.

If you have any doubts look at a few of the stickied threads to see the developers love for the community and the game, and notice that to date there are 377 Positive reveiws and only two negative :P

reviewText:
First off, I do recommend this game when it drops to around 5 bucks at most. I picked this game up on sale. At 15 dollars, no, this game is not worth it at all.

This is a simple tower defense game which only occupies a few screens across the entire game. Really isn't much to it. Feels like you are playing in a room or two.

The game is woefully unbalanced. For 90% of the game you can breeze by with only using Archers playing each level on it's hardest difficulty. This also means beating the game and then playing in game in it's second quest, which is just a repea of the game but harder. Problem is, the game is mostly a cakewalk until the end of the second quest where you hit this wall. And that is where the main problem is....

Grinding. FOr some odd reason this game has you grinding. This game takes Tower Defense and ads the worst element from an MMO - Grinding. Now, to beat the game I have to grind the same maps over and over and over, jsut to beat the final few levels.

Overall, did you find this while it had a 5 dollar price tag like I did? Buy it. It's fun up until the grinding hits. Did you find this game as it's full, overblown 15 dollar price tag? Avoid it completely.

reviewText: Defender's Quest is a case study in covering your weaknesses and emphasizing your strengths. Shoddy writing? A beautiful skip" button in every cutscene and dialogue can be turned off. Difficulty? If you hit a brick wall in story mode you can go back and do slightly harder versions of prior maps to level up. Tower diversity? Unique equipment means your second Berserker probably won't be as good as your first
date: so it's harder to spam one tower. The slog of New Game+ not going fast enough? Triple experience is an option in the menus. All this lets you focus on the core tower defense game
recommended: which is best played at 4X speed.\n\nPlenty of weaknesses can't be worked around
hoursPlayed: though. Workshop mods are few in number
voteText: and the first one I tried locked up the game in the first level. Character level is too huge a factor in whether you pass a level or not
helpfulPercent: meaning few maps feel appropriately scaled to your level at any given time. The game has a fixed resolution
votesHelpful: even in fullscreen
votesTotal: and in fullscreen Steam notifications will leave artifacts on the screen. It's a little too easy to fall into a "two of each" mentality
votesFunny: setting up two identical sets of towers on the two major paths of most maps
commentsCount: with the only major variance between maps being what towers you level up first. The tower "skill trees" don't contribute much especially for those towers that only have variants of "melee attack" or "shoot arrows".\n\nFor all the weaknesses I've pointed out
column16: there are few high points in the game. The boss fights are excellent
column17: requiring you to balance "kill the boss faster" against "kill the creeps faster". Otherwise it's the usual tower-defense game of setting up your towers and watching them slaughter thousands of zombies. The game demands enough of your attention in boosting your towers etcetera that it's not a good "put something on in the background while you play" game
column18: but isn't demanding enough to be a thoughtful or engaging experience.\n\nAll in all
column19: it's hard to recommend Defender's Quest unless you're just dying for a tower defense game where you make a bunch of bars go up a la Progress Quest."

reviewText:
Defender's Quest is a Tower-Defense/RPG Hybrid (Think Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense).

Defender's Quest tightly focuses on three things: tactical depth, customization, and story. That means no random encounters, no spikey-haired emo kids, no forced time sinks, and no tedious, repetitive battles.

The battle system builds off of tower defense, with individual characters taking the place of towers. Each character levels-up, learns skills, and equips gear individually, allowing the player to customize their battle experience and strategy. The overall game structure is similar to tactical" RPG's
date: but with a real-time battle system. Game speed is adjustable
recommended: and commands can even be issued while the game is paused.\n\nIt also features an engaging
hoursPlayed: character-driven story written by an actual English major! The story strives to be fast-paced
voteText: snappy
helpfulPercent: and always relevant to gameplay. Events and dialogue explain things as they become relevant to the player
votesHelpful: minimizing exposition.\n\nFinally
votesTotal: it's got options and accessibility settings out the wazoo
votesFunny: so that you can have the best possible experience!"

reviewText: The game has me hooked, but it has severe design flaws. The game plays in a small window. Being able to tell your units what type of enemy to target is nice, but the interface looks like a Windows 3.1 era spreadsheet program. It's too easy to spend money on the wrong upgrades and then not be sure if you're playing a level wrong or you just need to grind. (I got crushed on Karsk repeatedly until I figured out that I needed to go back to the last town and buy my main ranger a bow). The interface is so sloppy that you don't even get an error message when you try to spend a skill point on something you don't have the requirements for, it just makes the normal sound but does nothing. Each character you recruit is a different class, but you can recruit additional mute copies of the class who you level up separately which is... messy. Is there any other game where boosts" don't have a time limit?\n\nThe two Soulcaster games (not on Steam
date: but they're $1 each on Xbox indies) did the whole "Tower Defence but your towers are people" with better art

AFTER installing the game I got to read the EULA in which Level Up Labs reserves itself the right to collect ANY data from you (personally identifiable or not), change the privacy policy at ANY time (they just have to announce it on 'their' website without even mentioning a specific URL). I don't know if Level Up Labs has ill intent or are just way to inexperienced to write an EULA. But as of now this is their (more or less) legal binding EULA.
Therefore I refused the EULA and didn't get to play the game.

DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS GAME and only buy/install it, if you DON'T care about things like like this.

reviewText:
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is not a game for everyone and it is certainly not a game for me. There's a whole load of Tower Defense games out there in flash and they are free. Played several of them and they are certainly better than any games than this one.

There are free games that are much better. If you had paid full price of 15$ and you felt ripped-off for buying this game then I don't blame you.

reviewText:
Usually, tower defense games leave me cold.  Either so hard you have to micromanage every second, or so monotonous that it's just you doing the same thing over and over again.  This game is...different.

First of all, it has a plot.  It has a decent story.  It has humor.  It has rpg elements, collection elements, and it lets you choose how you want to play.  Lots of fighters?  Go for it.  Like ranged attacks?  You are good to go.  A decent blend?  Yup.  There is no one way to win a level...and you can replay the level to try other things.

Try this game...you'll enjoy it.

The classes (of which there are 6) all differ in playstyle and give the game its RPG elements via XP gains
date: talent trees and weapon/armor aquisition. Even though the game looks simple
recommended: it offers a very deep combat and leveling system which will have to be adjusted multiple times in order to beat certain levels. Examples include making your archers target fastest enemies first
hoursPlayed: putting the stun sword in the hands of your knight
voteText: or making sure your ice skills don't get cancelled by your burn ones.  The story itself is amusing as well and gave me a few chuckles along the way. New Game+

reviewText:
Bought this on a whim, wasn't expecting much, to be honest. But I do love tower defense, and it runs on linux, so I went ahead with the purchase. Very impressed, this game is actually very excellent and has an old-school SNES feel with modern tower defense. I've been playing it over more publicly accredited games (it actually has pulled me away from DOTA 2), so decided that a positive review would help out a bit because I feel very strongly about how this hidden gem wasted an entire Sunday for me, and I'm still not done beating it 100%. I rarely care about beating games 100%, I think the last time I did it was for a little-known title called Goldeneye in the 90's.


Excellent concept: merges RPG with tower defense. That's all there is to say, really. Units seem to be all useful, but as with ANY old-school RPG combat it can get super easy or impossible depending on whether or not you grind. Regardless on that, there are technically four difficulties (if you count casual) that change each battle's difficulty hugely. Story is alright -- the humor isn't my cup of tea, but then again, I have a picture of the dude from The Human Centipede 2 as my steam picture, so I just gotta say it's a me thing.

Looks like they're making a sequel. Good, I'll be sure to buy it.



If you're on linux and can't figure out why the game doesn't start without an error message, you need Adobe AIR. Their website is quite good on showing you how to get it running. A minor setback, I'm sure with licensing reasons Steam can't install it as a dependency. However, it almost made me assume the game was poorly ported and bugged (like Dead Island which doesn't boot on linux for some and nobody knows why, LOL).

The devs obviously cared a lot about this game: it's not junk meant to be sold to chumps where they buy it on sale, play for 15 minutes, then never open it up again. The writing is good -- not perfect, but meant to be (ugh) all ages. It's not a super deep story, though I feel with more practice they could pull it off if they feel it wouldn't detract from the gameplay in the sequel.

I would advise the devs to look at their website and tone down on the humor -- had my bored, cynical ♥♥♥ seen it without playing the game I would've assumed this game would be ♥♥♥♥.

The art isn't AAA title, but as an indie game, what the ♥♥♥♥ do you expect? The battles are mid 90's SNES quality (though better than Breath of Fire II, worse than FF6) and the cutscenes are adobe flash-esque and very similar to the indie game Sequence (minus the voice acting, plus more character gestures).

If the game was a teensy little longer and made for the SNES, with a little more professionalism" mixed in
date: it would've been a classic everyone would've known about.\n\nI came in expecting ♥♥♥♥ and found a gem I hadn't heard about before. I'm old
voteText: and this stole an entire day from me and perhaps longer. Def buy @ $10
helpfulPercent: even $15. It's about on par with binding of isaac."

reviewText:
This is a retro tower defense game. It is small in file size, but big in play! I like that I can easily run it in the background while I do other things on the computer.

The story progresses nicely. The characters are engaging, and I was never bored with the plot. You can complete the entire plot in a day even if you take your time. The graphics are in pixel style for the gameplay. The cut-scenes were artwork with text underneath. The art would move in response to the text moving, like reading an illustrated book.

This game has nice replay value. Every site on the map has 3 levels, easy, normal, and advanced. To unlock everything, you must beat all three. There are a lot of achievements in this game, and some of them are quite difficult to get. A single level can be solved in many different ways. And, the whole game can be played in newgame+ mode, which makes beating it a second time a new challenge.

Once I finished the plot, I found that I don't like to play for hours on end. The game is relaxing for me. I take my time with the higher level achievements. It's a fun, simple game and I recommend it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is a very simple, but fairly expansive Tower Defense (TD) game. you can gear out and upgrade your units how you want, and they all even have little tech trees for their abilities, though honestly I didn't really feel like the points I allocated did much to make any of the skills much better, but it's always fun to have that stuff I guess.

The levels are different formations and the monsters spawn from different points at different times depending on the level and difficulty. You can't do any forced pathing or anything like in defense grid but you still want to place your units so that they are getting in as many hits as possible. You can also set units to specific targeting types, whether it's whatever enemy is closest to the end of the trail, the one with highest HP, lowest HP, etc...

All in all this is a good little TD, I wouldn't recommend buying it unless it's on sale for like 5-8 bucks though.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Defender's Quest is a tower defense style game with RPG-based elements added in.  I liked it; overall, it's a quaint little game.  The characters are likable and the story (although not too original) is well paced and engaging enough.  There were a few times where the gameplay felt a little grindy to me (make sure you level up more than one priest, for example - I didn't and had to grind one up before I could proceed) but you can redo levels on harder difficulties for more experience and money or on easier difficulties to move the game along.

Eventually, I just started playing on easy to advance the story along, then I just quit playing altogether.  Although I didn't finish it I still liked the game and would recommend it to fans of TDs, especially if the added RPG elements interest you.

I also liked how it asked you to like the author on Facebook or something to get a free item at the beginning.  I always give games that ask me to do this a resounding, Hell No!" and when I did with Defender's Quest it gave me the items anyway
date: so I thought that was nice.\n\nNothing to write home about
recommended: but it wasn't a bad attempt.  You'll probably enjoy your time with this game."

reviewText:
So I won this game in a giveaway where I got to choose which game I wanted out of a list, major shout out to toph--Such a nice person! Honestly this was my third choice, and it appealed to me because im a sucker for pixel art in games like this, and the old final fantasies, and man did i fall in love with this game.

It's rich in story content, a great tower defense game where you can grind for currency and leveling up, and complete stages at harder difficulties to gain bonus loot, has a great soundtrack, and i swear that they sampled a battle theme from Final Fantasy 8 i swear i hear it exactly in the background of each stage with minor changes to it, which I absolutely love, I love the music in this game, the fact that you can customize the classes that you recruit, their talent tree, the fact that you can give them gear and make them stronger.

This is like no other tower defense game, its got personality, as do the characters, this is no crystal defenders clone, its got its own label, in fact i think its much more elaborate and more fun than crystal defenders which I am a big fan of. All the gear customization reminds me of Fantasy Defense on Android which I was a big fan of as well.

This game is defintely a gem that people should look into buying.

I am so stoked for Defender's Quest 2

reviewText: This is the Best tower defense game I ever played.  Is it the best ever? Probably not.  It is a tower defense with set paths on every map, no path customizing (altering) at all which i would say is a strategic element required for it to be the best ever.  But it does have an actual story which makes sense of enemies getting to the goal point, never seen that in a TD game. Story is ok, some good humor, skill trees for units who gain persistent levels, over 10 hours of gameplay on initial game mode (far more if you want to unlock everything), and after beating it it unlocks a different and harder game mode.  All these things combined give this game far more depth and play time then any TD game I've played and I've played quite a few. It could be made better and I am hoping for a sequel. This game is worth 10 bucks if its up your alley, 7 or so if you arent sure. It's already been cheaper though.

reviewText:
I got this game as part of a humble bundle and immediatly saw that it is a tower defence game, which deterred me a little, however, as it is a small game to download, I figured I'd give it a try.
Thus far I have enjoyed the game for a number of reasons;
The first being that the characters all have interesting personalities.
The next being that the cutscenes are humorous, with jokes that are reminiscent of Dragonfable, but still fresh.
Finally, you have a fairly large number of strategic choices with how you set your units, and which ones you power up.

I would recommend this game, especially if you are looking for a tower defence game which can be run on low-end computers, or if you simply enjoy the tower defence genre.

reviewText:
I want to state this as plainly as possible first: I hate pixel-art games.  I find them to be a lazy way to do art and a cheap grab for indie devs.

With that said, this game is great, and it taught me that pixel-art is okay if the game mechanics make up for it, which this one does extremely well.

The blend of RPG and TD is done extremely well.  The story is mediocre, but it does help the progression of the game along.

There are enough RPG mechanics in this game and uniqueness among the towers" and enemies that you will enjoy going back and doing the levels over again at higher difficulties for the loot and to level your party.

If you like tower defense and you like RPGs somewhat reminiscent of classic Final Fantasy

reviewText:
This is a retro tower defense game. It is small in file size, but big in play! I like that I can easily run it in the background while I do other things on the computer.

The story progresses nicely. The characters are engaging, and I was never bored with the plot. You can complete the entire plot in a day even if you take your time. The graphics are in pixel style for the gameplay. The cut-scenes were artwork with text underneath. The art would move in response to the text moving, like reading an illustrated book.

This game has nice replay value. Every site on the map has 3 levels, easy, normal, and advanced. To unlock everything, you must beat all three. There are a lot of achievements in this game, and some of them are quite difficult to get. A single level can be solved in many different ways. And, the whole game can be played in newgame+ mode, which makes beating it a second time a new challenge.

Once I finished the plot, I found that I don't like to play for hours on end. The game is relaxing for me. I take my time with the higher level achievements. It's a fun, simple game and I recommend it.

reviewText:
This is a game where battles take place in a tower defense style, but you progress by roaming around a map while fighting these battles. Has elements of the old Shining Force / Disgaea games where:

reviewText: I always had a certain fondness for tower defense. In StarCraft, I'd spend more time stacking cannons than playing the ladder, and Team Fortress 2's MvM mode reveals a certain primal fun of killing tons of heartless, unfeeling dudes. To that end, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten presents a well-rounded, core dude-killing experience, but the cracks in the polish are evident.\n\nYou're given six classes to play, all fairly standard for the genre: heavy damage, light damage, healer, ranged, status effects, and tank. Upgrade trees for each class are fleshed out for the game's length, and most powers are distinct from the moment you first receive them. Leveling up your characters before and during battle using Psi" adds a certain urgency to the fight
date: and doesn't feel forced.\n\nBut between battles there exists some friction between the player and the imperfect interface. Between the fast-forward of battle and the clunky number-comparison engine to power up your party
recommended: you'll be wishing for a patch to streamline or automate the process. You could do worse but you could do better; not even trendy not-loading-but-loading-messages like 'reticulating splines' or 'powering up the thermal core' are to be seen. You might hope to find some solace in the story
hoursPlayed: but it's just as hacked-on as the interface and I couldn't be bothered to follow it.\n\nMy first playthrough entailed of spamming rangers (long-range) with the range upgrade and blew through the game without breaking a sweat
voteText: but in Hero Mode
helpfulPercent: where you limit yourself to one of each class
votesHelpful: is where the game's difficulty felt most appropriate. Oftentimes you'll have three or four spawn points to deal with
votesTotal: and you'll need to consider the most optimal placement to cover all your bases
votesFunny: evoking the puzzle modes of yore.\n\nAll in all I'm giving this a weak recommendation. The game itself is pretty solid - gameplay is mostly balanced
commentsCount: and it can be as hard as you want it to be. The lore isn't engaging and you won't miss much from skipping it; on the other hand
column16: if you're the type for a story maybe tower defense wasn't going to be your cup of tea anyway. If it goes on sale again for 90% off you'll get a fun one-off to pick up and play
column17: not unlike something you'd find on a phone or tablet. Otherwise
column18: you may feel you aren't getting enough bang for your buck."

reviewText: This is a diamond in the rough for tower defense games. There are six different classes of units, and you can recuit a maximum of six units per class. Each level has four difficulties and three stars. There's an overarching plot to tie the levels together. Some levels require strategic use of only certain units, and level layouts are such that you are forced to thoughtfully place units to maximize their contribution.\n\nItem upgrades were added recently, and New Game+ mode keeps the fun going for more than twice as long as the original game. I've played this game for a long time, since before it even landed on steam, and I still haven't acquired the highest level items. I still haven't finished beating levels. I still haven't gotten my fill of this fun game.

reviewText:
One of the best tower defense games I've played so far.

Rather than a typical tower defense game that you can find around steam, they insert a few interesting RPG element into the mix, and it works suprisingly well. Each tower is actually a character and each character has levels, skill trees and equipments. Each character helps progress in the main stroryline, and the storyline is pretty interesting and funny at times.

Most importantly, the game runs great and destroying the waves of enemies with your smart strategic placement of towers/characters is satisfying. It has a lot of levels, multiple difficulties for each level, has bonus levels like endless mode, new game + and has Steam Workshop to add new stuff!

If you're a fan of RPG and tower defense, this is definitely a game you cannot miss.

8/10, great game.

reviewText: This game is quite addictive and I've been impressed with the details that provide a lot of replay value. As with any tower defense game, your goal is to prevent enemy units from reaching your tower. In this case, your tower is a librarian who has obtained magical powers to battle in the realm between life and death. To defend herself, she can cast some magic spells and she can pull her allies (berserkers, archers, healers, knights, ice mages, and dragons) into her realm and position them for defense. Besides the librarian, all units act on their own once placed. The defenders' skills and the librarian's spells can all be leveled up by earning experience. The skill trees, along with armor and weapons, provide the ability to customize each defender's strengths.\n\nWhat makes the game addictive is the variation. Each battle provides a different set of enemies and a different map with sometimes challenging unit placement options. As the game progresses, the type, number, and skill of available defenders increases which provides for different strategies to be employed. Each battle can also be completed at one of four difficulty levels, with higher levels producing different, more powerful, more numerous enemies. Completing battles perfectly (with no tower damage) unlocks bonus levels for additional variation. Once the main story is completed (10 - 20 hours depending on replays, bonus levels, etc.), a Play+" option allows the story to be run again
date: this time with additional side quests
voteText: etc. The librarian's journal is also unlocked
helpfulPercent: adding some more humor to the game (which was already very light hearted in tone)."

reviewText:
Let's be honest: you will not be super impressed with the graphics and the game play is not going to astound you with its originality.

Now that's out of the way I suggest you play it. Play it for its addictive tower defence game that allows you to select the challenge to suit your play stile and rewards you for trying higher difficulty. Play it for the light hearted dialogue and story engaging enough to keep dragging you to the next level. If you have played tower defence games then you are not going to be surprised by anything here but RPG elements add depth and an attachment to characters that make it a richer experience than some.

I purchased this game with the intention of it being a casual gaming experience. The fact that I was playing it until 2am says that, for me at least this was an enjoyable and addictive experience and I am looking forward to seeing what the sequel will bring (probably more late nights).

reviewText: I am a huge fan of Tower Defense games, but it's been a while since I've seen anything this fun. Getting the rhythm of the game is relatively easy, and the difficulty slowly grows with your characters, so it never feels too easy unless you've done some serious grinding in order to gear out your Heroes. The best part is the strategy, but the humour is definitely up there. If you like twisted humour, you will love this game. Slak and Wrenna are the absolute best when it comes to the jokes (though I wish Ice Mages were a bit more useful than just being a slow spam).

reviewText:
I like Tower Defense games, and I found this to be an enjoyable entry in the genre. There's a lot of management options throughout each battle: the ability to cast spells, to recall and replace units for better effect, and upgrade units on the fly. There are time acceleration/deceleration options to reduce the grind if you've got an efficient unit setup and just want to get the battle done, or for if things get intense and you need to suddenly micromange your setup.

You can also modify the experience bonuses/penalties for the game so that, if you don't have a lot of time to play, you can compress the game progression to reduce the grind even further. Frankly, it's an elegant and user-friendly setup for even the most casual of gamer.

The RPG element to this one is a nice twist, and there is a decent amount of replayability via the New Game+ mode.

But if there is anything which truly makes this game shine, it's the writing.
This game has made me laugh until my lungs protested, and has resulted in my replaying the game multiple times just for the dialogue.

I highly recommend it even at full price. And if you see it on special, grab it immediately.

reviewText: I'm not strongly into tower defense games, but this does away with some of the downsides of tower defense games. You do not have limitless towers, as the towers are characters. They are along for the ride, so they gain XP after each battle. If the game becomes too hard, you can replay an earlier level; however, this is not grindy-feeling, since the previous levels can be played at a higher difficulty (with more rewards). (And if you *really* don't like grinding, you can increase the XP gain.) Slak says to at least try the demo; pants are optional.
